revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=May 2013}} {{Year box}} '''1938 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Alpine skiing]]== '''FIS Alpine World Ski Championships''' 8th [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 1938|FIS Alpine World Ski Championships]] are held at [[Engelberg]], Switzerland. The events are a [[Downhill (ski competition)|downhill]], a [[Slalom skiing|slalom]] and a [[Alpine skiing combined|combined]] race in both the men's and women's categories. The winners are: * Men's Downhill – [[James Couttet]] (France) * Men's Slalom – [[Rudolf Rominger]] (Switzerland) * Men's Combined – [[Emile Allais]] (France) * Women's Downhill – [[Lisa Resch]] (Germany) * Women's Slalom – [[Christl Cranz]] (Germany) * Women's Combined – [[Christl Cranz]] (Germany)
==[[American football]]== * [[1938 New York Giants season|New York Giants]] 23–17 [[1938 Green Bay Packers season|Green Bay Packers]] for the [[1938 NFL Championship Game|NFL]] title. * First [[Oil Bowl (high school)|High School Oil Bowl]] is played.
==[[Association football]]== '''World Cup''' * [[1938 FIFA World Cup|1938 World Cup]] held in France – [[Italy national football team|Italy]] retain their title, beating [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]] 4-2 in the final. '''England''' * [[Football League First Division|First Division]] – [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] win the [[1937–38 in English football|1937–38]] title * [[FA Cup]] – [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] beat [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] 1-0 '''Spain''' * [[La Liga]] – not contested due to the [[Spanish Civil War]] '''Germany''' * [[1938 German football championship|German football championship]] won by [[Hannover 96]] '''Italy''' * [[1937–38 Serie A|Serie A]] won by [[F.C. Internazionale Milano|Ambrosiana-Inter]] '''Portugal''' * [[1937–38 Primeira Liga|Primeira Liga]] won by [[S.L. Benfica]] '''France''' * [[1937–38 French Division 1|French Division 1]] won by [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux-Montbéliard]]
==[[Athletics (track and field)|Athletics]]== * March 3 – [[Glenn Cunningham (runner)|Glenn Cunningham]] breaks the world record for the indoor mile run by completing the distance in 4 minutes, 4.4 seconds. * September 4 – [[1938 European Championships in Athletics|European Championships Marathon]] at Paris is won by [[Väinö Muinonen]] (Finland) in a time of 2:37:29
==[[Australian rules football]]== * The [[Victorian Football Association]] legalized throwing the ball in general play, establishing its own code of Australian rules football which was distinct from the national code administered by the [[Australian National Football Council]].<ref name="experiment">{{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|date=16 February 1938|title=Football experiments|page=24|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|author=Percy Taylor}}</ref> It was the beginning of a [[Australian rules football schism (1938–1949)|decade-long schism]] which ran from 1938 until 1949. * '''[[1938 VFL season|Victorian Football League]]''' ** 24 September – [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]] wins the 42nd VFL Premiership, defeating [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] 15.10 (100) to 13.7 (85) in the [[1938 VFL Grand Final]] ** [[Brownlow Medal]] awarded to [[Dick Reynolds]] ([[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]]) * '''[[South Australian National Football League]]''' ** 1 October – [[South Adelaide Football Club|South Adelaide]] 23.14 (152) defeat [[Port Adelaide Football Club (SANFL)|Port Adelaide]] 15.16 (106) in the [[1938 SANFL Grand Final]] ** [[Magarey Medal]] won by [[Bob Quinn (Australian footballer)|Bob Quinn]] (Port Adelaide) * '''[[1938 WANFL season|Western Australian National Football League]]''' ** 15 October – [[Claremont Football Club|Claremont]] 15.11 (101) defeat [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] 11.13 (79) to win their first WANFL premiership in the Grand Final Replay, after the Tigers had scored 13.16 (94) to Old Easts’ 14.10 (94) in the first Grand Final on 8 October. ** [[Sandover Medal]] won by [[Haydn Bunton, Sr.]] ([[Subiaco Football Club|Subiaco]])
==[[Baseball]]== * [[World Series]] – [[1938 New York Yankees season|New York Yankees]] defeat [[1938 Chicago Cubs season|the Chicago Cubs]], 4–0. * [[Baseball Hall of Fame balloting, 1938|Hall of Fame election]] – Continuing toward the goal of 10 initial inductees at the 1939 opening of the Hall, voters select [[Grover Cleveland Alexander]]. A special committee selects organizer [[Alexander Cartwright]] and promoter [[Henry Chadwick (writer)|Henry Chadwick]]; selections of 19th century players are again postponed. * [[Starting pitcher]] [[Johnny Vander Meer]] ([[1938 Cincinnati Reds season|Cincinnati Reds]]) throws back–to–back [[no-hitter]]s, meaning they came in two consecutive starts, something not accomplished before or since. * March 1 – Nankai Hawks, officially founded in [[Japanese Baseball League]], as predecessor of [[Fukuoka SoftBank Hawks]].{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
==[[Basketball]]== '''NBL Championship'''
*[[Akron Goodyear Wingfoots]] win two games to one over the [[Oshkosh All-Stars]]
'''Events''' * The sixth [[South American Basketball Championship 1938|South American Basketball Championship]] in [[Lima]] is won by [[Peru national basketball team|Peru]].
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * American boxer [[Henry Armstrong]] simultaneously holds the welterweight, lightweight, and featherweight world titles. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Joe Louis]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[John Henry Lewis]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – vacant * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Barney Ross]] → [[Henry Armstrong]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Lou Ambers]] → [[Henry Armstrong]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Henry Armstrong]] → vacant * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Harry Jeffra]] → [[Sixto Escobar]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – [[Benny Lynch]] → vacant → [[Peter Kane]]
==[[Commonwealth Games|British Empire Games]]== * February – [[Commonwealth Games|British Empire Games]] held in Sydney
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * 24 August – [[England cricket team|England]] defeat [[Australian cricket team|Australia]] by an innings and 579 runs, the biggest winning margin in [[Test cricket]] history.<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Records/Test/Overall/Team/Highest_Innings_Run_Margin.html Test Cricket – Highest Innings Winning Margin]</ref> '''[[1938 English cricket season|England]]''' * [[County Championship]] – won by [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – won by [[Buckinghamshire County Cricket Club|Buckinghamshire]] * Most runs – [[Wally Hammond]] 3,011 @ 75.27 (HS 271) * Most wickets – [[Arthur Wellard]] 172 @ 20.29 (BB 7–59) * England and Australia tie one Test each with two draws * ''[[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]]'' – [[Hugh Bartlett]], [[Bill Brown (cricketer)|Bill Brown]], [[Denis Compton]], [[Ken Farnes|Kenneth Farnes]], [[Arthur Wood (cricketer, born 1898)|Arthur Wood]] '''Australia''' * Sheffield Shield won by [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]] * Most runs – [[Don Bradman]] 1,437 @ 89.81 (HS 246) * Most wickets **[[Bill O'Reilly (cricketer)|Bill O‘Reilly]] 64 @ 12.25 (BB 9-41) **[[Chuck Fleetwood-Smith]] 64 @ 22.43 (BB 9-135) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular|Bombay Pentangular]] – [[Muslims cricket team|Muslims]] * [[Ranji Trophy]] – [[Hyderabad cricket team|Hyderabad]] beat [[Nawanagar cricket team|Nawanagar]] by one wicket '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – won by [[Transvaal cricket team|Transvaal]] and [[Natal cricket team|Natal]] (shared) '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – won by [[Auckland cricket team|Auckland]] '''West Indies''' * Inter-Colonial Tournament – won by [[British Guiana cricket team|British Guiana]]
==[[Cycling]]== '''[[1938 Tour de France|Tour de France]]''' * [[Gino Bartali]] wins the 32nd Tour de France '''[[1938 Giro d'Italia|Giro d'Italia]]''' * [[Giovanni Valetti]] of Fréjus wins the 26th Giro d'Italia
==[[Figure skating]]== * [[1938 World Figure Skating Championships|World Figure Skating Championships]] – ** Men's champion: [[Felix Kaspar]], Austria ** Ladies' champion: [[Megan Taylor]], Great Britain ** Pair skating champion: [[Maxi Herber]] & [[Ernst Baier]], Germany
==[[Golf]]== '''Men's professional''' * [[1938 Masters Tournament|Masters Tournament]] – [[Henry Picard]] * [[1938 U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] – [[Ralph Guldahl]] * [[1938 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Reg Whitcombe]] * [[1938 PGA Championship|PGA Championship]] – [[Paul Runyan]] '''Men's amateur''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Charlie Yates]] * [[U.S. Amateur]] – [[Willie Turnesa]] '''Women's professional''' * [[Women's Western Open]] – [[Bea Barrett]] * [[Titleholders Championship]] – [[Patty Berg]]
==[[Horse racing]]== * In what is billed as the “Match of the Century”, [[Seabiscuit]] defeats the US [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing]] champion, [[War Admiral]]. '''Steeplechases''' * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] – [[Morse Code (horse)|Morse Code]] * [[1938 Grand National|Grand National]] – [[Battleship (horse)|Battleship]] '''Hurdle races''' * [[Champion Hurdle]] – [[Our Hope]] '''Flat races''' * Australia – [[Melbourne Cup]] won by [[Catalogue (horse)|Catalogue]] * Canada – [[Queen's Plate]] won by [[Bunty Lawless]] * France – [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] won by [[Eclair au Chocolat]] * Ireland – [[Irish Derby Stakes]] won by [[Rosewell (horse)|Rosewell]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|English Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Pasch (horse)|Pasch]] *# [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Bois Roussel]] *# [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Scottish Union]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|United States Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[1938 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – [[Lawrin]] *# [[Preakness Stakes]] – [[War Admiral]] *# [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[War Admiral]]
==[[Ice hockey]]== * [[1937–38 Chicago Blackhawks season|Chicago Blackhawks]] defeat [[1937–38 Toronto Maple Leafs season|the Toronto Maple Leafs]] three games to one [[1938 Stanley Cup Finals|in the Stanley Cup final series]].
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1938 in motorsport|List of 1938 motorsport champions}}
==[[Nordic skiing]]== '''FIS Nordic World Ski Championships''' * 11th [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 1938]] are held at [[Lahti]], Finland
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 2 April — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 90th [[The Boat Race 1938|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== *[[1938 European Rugby League Championship]] / [[1938–39 European Rugby League Championship]] *[[1938 New Zealand rugby league season]] *[[1938 NSWRFL season]] *[[1937–38 Northern Rugby Football League season]] / [[1938–39 Northern Rugby Football League season]]
==[[Rugby union]]== * 51st [[1938 Home Nations Championship|Home Nations Championship]] series is won by [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]]
==[[Skiing]]== * The [[Cannon Mountain (New Hampshire)|Cannon Mountain]] Aerial Tramway, the first [[aerial tramway]] in the United States, opens at [[Cannon Mountain Ski Area]].
==[[Snooker]]== * [[World Snooker Championship]] – [[Joe Davis]] beats [[Sidney Smith (snooker player)|Sidney Smith]] 37–24
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[World Allround Speed Skating Championships for Men|Men's All-round Champion]] – [[Ivar Ballangrud]] (Norway) * [[World Allround Speed Skating Championships for Women|Women's All-round Champion]] – [[Laila Schou Nilsen]] (Norway)
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Don Budge]] (USA) defeats [[John Bromwich]] (Australia) 6–4, 6–2, 6–1 * [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Dorothy Cheney]] (USA) defeats [[Dorothy Stevenson]] (Australia) 6–3, 6–2 '''England''' * [[List of Wimbledon Gentlemen's Singles champions|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Don Budge]] (USA) defeats Bunny Austin (Great Britain) 6–1, 6–0, 6–3 * [[List of Wimbledon Ladies' Singles champions|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Helen Wills Moody]] (USA) defeats [[Helen Jacobs]] (USA) 6–4, 6–0 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Don Budge]] (USA) defeats [[Roderich Menzel]] (Czechoslovakia) 6–3, 6–2, 6–4 * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Simonne Mathieu]] (France) defeats [[Nelly Adamson Landry]] (France) 6–0, 6–3 '''USA''' * [[List of US Open Men's Singles champions|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Don Budge]] (USA) defeats [[Gene Mako]] (USA) 6–3, 6–8, 6–2, 6–1 * [[List of US Open Women's Singles champions|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Alice Marble]] (USA) defeats [[Nancye Wynne Bolton]] (Australia) 6–0, 6–3 '''Events''' * [[Don Budge]] becomes the first male tennis player to complete the [[Grand Slam in tennis]] of all 4 Championships. '''Davis Cup''' * [[1938 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|USA|1912}} 3–2 {{davis|AUS}} at [[Germantown Cricket Club]] (grass) [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]], [[United States]]
==Awards== * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Male Athlete of the Year]] – [[Don Budge]], [[Tennis]] * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Female Athlete of the Year]] – [[Patty Berg]], [[LPGA|LPGA golf]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1901 – 1950}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1938 in sports| ]]

{{infobox sport event |name = 1971 Swaythling Cup (Men's Team) |image = |size = |caption = |date_start = |date_end = |competitors = |nations = |prize_money = |other = |venue = |location = |prev = [[1969 World Table Tennis Championships – Men's Team|1969]] |next = [[1973 World Table Tennis Championships – Men's Team|1973]] }} {{main|1971 World Table Tennis Championships}} The '''1971 World Table Tennis Championships – Swaythling Cup (Men's Team)''' was the 31st edition of the men's team championship.{{cite web|url=http://www.allabouttabletennis.com/world-table-tennis-championships-medal-winners.html|title=List of Winners|publisher=All About Tennis}} {{cite book|last=Montague|first=Trevor|title=A-Z of Sport, pages 699-700|year=2004|publisher=The Bath Press|isbn=0-316-72645-1}} China won the [[gold medal]] defeating Japan 5-2 in the final. Yugoslavia won the [[bronze medal]] after winning the third place play off.{{cite book|last=Matthews/Morrison|first=Peter/Ian|title=The Guinness Encyclopaedia of Sports Records and Results, pages 309-312|year=1987|publisher=Guinness Superlatives|isbn=0-85112-492-5}} {{cite web|url=http://sports123.com/tte/index.html|title=Table Tennis World Championship medal winners|publisher=Sports123}} {{cite web|url=http://www.tischtennis-infos.de/content/download/ittf-turniere/|title=Swaythling Cup results|publisher=tischtennis-infos.de}} {{cite web|url=https://tabletennisengland.co.uk/etta_website/magazine-archive/1970-71/tt_issue238.pdf|title=1971 Swaythling Cup results|publisher=Table Tennis England}} ==Medalists== {| {{MedalistTable|type=Event}} |- | | {{flagcountry|CHN}}

{{main|1996 Fed Cup}} The '''Americas Zone''' was one of three zones of regional competition in the [[1996 Fed Cup]]. ==Group I== * Venue: [[Club Palestino]], [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]], [[Chile]] (outdoor clay) * Date: 22–28 April The eight teams were divided into two pools of four teams. The top two teams of each pool play-off in a two-round knockout stage to decide which nation progresses to [[1996 Fed Cup World Group II Play-offs|World Group II play-offs]]. Nations finishing in the bottom place in each pool were relegated to Americas Zone Group II for 1997. ===Pools=== {{col-float-begin|width=35em}} {{4TeamRR | title=[[1996 Fed Cup Americas Zone Group I – Pool A|Pool A]] | team-1-abbrev=CHI | team-1={{fed|CHI}} (3–0) | team-2-abbrev=COL | team-2={{fed|COL}} (2–1) | team-3-abbrev=MEX | team-3={{fed|MEX}} (1–2) | team-4-abbrev=PAR | team-4={{nowrap|{{fed|PAR}} (0–3)}} | 1v2=2–1 |1v3=2–1 |1v4=2–1 |2v1=1–2 | 2v3=2–1 |2v4=2–1 |3v1=1–2 |3v2=1–2 | 3v4=2–1 |4v1=1–2 |4v2=1–2 |4v3=1–2 }} {{col-float-break|width=35em}} {{4TeamRR | title=[[1996 Fed Cup Americas Zone Group I – Pool B|Pool B]] | team-1-abbrev=VEN | team-1={{fed|VEN|1930}} (3–0) | team-2-abbrev=BRA | team-2={{fed|BRA}} (2–1) | team-3-abbrev=PUR | team-3={{nowrap|{{fed|PUR}} (1–2)}} | team-4-abbrev=URU | team-4={{fed|URU}} (0–3) | 1v2=3–0 |1v3=3–0 |1v4=3–0 |2v1=0–3 | 2v3=3–0 |2v4=3–0 |3v1=0–3 |3v2=0–3 | 3v4=2–1 |4v1=0–3 |4v2=0–3 |4v3=1–2 }} {{col-float-end}} ===Knockout Stage=== {{main|1996 Fed Cup Americas Zone Group I – Knockout Stage}} {{2RoundBracket-Byes | RD1='''Semifinals'''
27 April | RD2='''Final'''
28 April | RD1-seed1=  | RD1-team1='''{{fed|CHI}} | RD1-score1='''2 | RD1-seed2=  | RD1-team2={{fed|BRA}} | RD1-score2=1 | RD1-seed3=  | RD1-team3='''{{fed|COL}} | RD1-score3='''2 | RD1-seed4=  | RD1-team4={{fed|VEN|1930}} | RD1-score4=1 | RD2-seed1=  | RD2-team1='''{{fed|CHI}} | RD2-score1='''2 | RD2-seed2=  | RD2-team2={{fed|COL}} | RD2-score2=1 }} * '''{{fed|CHI}}''' advanced to World Group II Play-offs.{{cite news|url=http://www.fedcup.com/en/results/tie/details.aspx?tieId=20003543|title=Croatia v Chile|publisher=fedcup.com}} * ''{{fed|PAR}}'' and ''{{fed|URU}}'' relegated to Group II in 1997.{{cite news|url=http://www.fedcup.com/en/results/tie/details.aspx?tieId=20004428|title=Paraguay v Panama|publisher=fedcup.com}}{{cite news|url=http://www.fedcup.com/en/results/tie/details.aspx?tieId=20004299|title=Uruguay v Jamaica|publisher=fedcup.com}} ==Group II== * Venue: [[Santo Domingo]], [[Dominican Republic]] (outdoor clay) * Date: 6–12 May The thirteen teams were divided into two pools of six and seven. The top team from each pool then moved would advance to Group I for 1997. ===Pools=== {{col-float-begin|width=40em}} {{6TeamRR | title=[[1996 Fed Cup Americas Zone Group II – Pool A|Pool A]] | team-1-abbrev=ECU | team-1={{fed|ECU}} (5–0) | team-2-abbrev=BOL | team-2={{fed|BOL}} (4–1) | team-3-abbrev=ESA | team-3={{nowrap|{{fed|ESA}} (3–2)}} | team-4-abbrev=GUA | team-4={{fed|GUA}} (2–3) | team-5-abbrev=BAH | team-5={{fed|BAH}} (1–4) | team-6-abbrev=BAR | team-6={{fed|BAR}} (0–5) | 1v2=3–0 |1v3=3–0 |1v4=3–0 |1v5=3–0 |1v6=3–0 |2v1=0–3 |2v3=3–0 |2v4=3–0 |2v5=3–0 |2v6=3–0 |3v1=0–3 |3v2=0–3 |3v4=3–0 |3v5=3–0 |3v6=3–0 |4v1=0–3 |4v2=0–3 |4v3=0–3 |4v5=2–1 |4v6=3–0 |5v1=0–3 |5v2=0–3 |5v3=0–3 |5v4=1–2 |5v6=2–1 |6v1=0–3 |6v2=0–3 |6v3=0–3 |6v4=0–3 |6v5=1–2 }} {{col-float-break|width=40em}} |3v7=3–0 |4v1=0–3 |4v2=0–3 |4v3=1–2 |4v5=3–0 |4v6=2–1 |4v7=2–1 |5v1=1–2 |5v2=0–3 |5v3=0–3 |5v4=0–3 |5v6=2–1 |5v7=3–0 |6v1=0–3 |6v2=0–3 |6v3=1–2 |6v4=1–2 |6v5=1–2 |6v7=3–0 |7v1=0–3 |7v2=0–3 |7v3=0–3 |7v4=1–2 |7v5=0–3 |7v6=0–3 }} {{col-float-end}} * '''{{fed|ECU}}''' and '''{{fed|PER}}''' advanced to Group I in 1997.{{cite news|url=http://www.fedcup.com/en/results/tie/details.aspx?tieId=20003418|title=Canada v Ecuador|publisher=fedcup.com}}{{cite news|url=http://www.fedcup.com/en/results/tie/details.aspx?tieId=20004725|title=Peru v Puerto Rico|publisher=fedcup.com}} ==See also== *[[Fed Cup structure]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{refbegin|colwidth=30em}} * [http://www.fedcup.com/en/teams/team/profile.aspx?id=CHI Fed Cup Profile, Chile] * [http://www.fedcup.com/en/teams/team/profile.aspx?id=COL Fed Cup Profile, Colombia] * [http://www.fedcup.com/en/teams/team/profile.aspx?id=MEX Fed Cup Profile, Mexico] * [http://www.fedcup.com/en/teams/team/profile.aspx?id=VEN Fed Cup Profile, Venezuela] * [http://www.fedcup.com/en/teams/team/profile.aspx?id=BRA Fed Cup Profile, Brazil] * [http://www.fedcup.com/en/teams/team/profile.aspx?id=PUR Fed Cup Profile, Puerto Rico] * [http://www.fedcup.com/en/teams/team/profile.aspx?id=ECU Fed Cup Profile, Ecuador] * [http://www.fedcup.com/en/teams/team/profile.aspx?id=BOL Fed Cup Profile, Bolivia] * [http://www.fedcup.com/en/teams/team/profile.aspx?id=ESA Fed Cup Profile, El Salvador] * [http://www.fedcup.com/en/teams/team/profile.aspx?id=GUA Fed Cup Profile, Guatemala] * {{infobox football tournament season | title = Lebanese FA Cup | year = 2015-2016 | country = {{flag|Lebanon}} | num_teams = 16 | champions = [[Nejmeh SC]] | runner-up = [[Al Ahed]] | matches = 15 | goals = 44 | prevseason = [[2014-15 Lebanese FA Cup|2014-2015]] | nextseason = [[2016-2017 Lebanese FA Cup|2016-2017]] }}{{unref|date=February 2017}} The 2015-2016 edition of the '''[[Lebanese FA Cup]]''' is the 44th edition to be played. It is the premier knockout tournament for football teams in Lebanon.
The winners qualify for the [[2017 AFC Cup]].
The tournament began in 22/1/2016 in a match between Shabab Al Sahel and Al Egtemaaey Tripoli. The final was played in 5/6/2016 between Nejmeh SC and Al Ahed.
{{DEFAULTSORT:2015-16 Lebanese FA Cup}} [[Category:2015–16 in Lebanese football|Cup]] [[Category:Lebanese FA Cup seasons]]
{{Lebanon-footy-competition-stub}}

revision.text:
{{pp-pc1}} {{Use British English|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{about|the wife of footballer Steven Gerrard|the rugby league player|Alex Gerrard (rugby league)}} {{Infobox model | name = Alex Curran | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Alexandra Curran | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1982|09|23|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Aintree]], [[Merseyside]], England | death_date = | death_place = | height = {{height|ft=5|in=9}}[http://ifdb.co/models/alex_curran/1225 The Internet Fashion Database] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110816105613/http://ifdb.co/models/alex_curran/1225 |date=16 August 2011 }} Retrieved and verified on 29 May 2011 | haircolour = Blonde | eyecolour = Blue | website = | spouse = [[Steven Gerrard]]
(2007{{ndash}}present) }} '''Alexandra Gerrard''' ([[née]] '''Curran'''; born 23 September 1982) is an English model, fashion columnist for the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'', and the wife of former [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[English national football team|England]] [[Captain (association football)|captain]] [[Steven Gerrard]]. She was described as a leading "[[WAGs|WAG]]" of the England national football team, along with women such as [[Victoria Beckham]] and [[Coleen Rooney]]. In 2007, the ''[[The Times|Times]]'' referred to her, then Steven Gerrard's fiancée, as an "''über''-WAG"."tussling over the remote with his ''über''-WAG fiancée" – ''[[The Times|Times]]'' Magazine, 17 February 2007 On 29 October 2007, she launched her own fragrance, named "Alex", which was one of the top sellers of 2007.[http://www.sundayherald.com/life/people/display.var.1891433.0.scents_sensibility.php Scents and Sensibility] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090101025641/http://www.sundayherald.com/life/people/display.var.1891433.0.scents_sensibility.php |date=1 January 2009 }}, ''[[Sunday Herald]]'', 8 December 2007 ==Writing== Curran writes a weekly [[newspaper column|column]] for the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'', titled "Go Shopping With Alex Curran". She wrote a weekly column for OK Magazine from 2009 until January 2013.[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/may/25/g2 Lost in Showbiz], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 25 May 2007 ==Personal life== A former [[manicure|nail technician]], Curran was born in [[Aintree]], Merseyside and raised in [[Maghull]], and attended [[Maghull High School]]. Curran and Steven Gerrard have been a couple since 2002.Interview with Alex Curran, ''[[Sunday People]]'', 13 May 2005 [https://web.archive.org/web/20080731205211/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4161/is_20050313/ai_n12944334 Online version] Prior to her relationship with Gerrard, Curran was dating businessman Tony Richardson, while Gerrard was dating [[Jennifer Ellison]]. At some point in 2002, Curran and Ellison switched lovers; ''[[The Guardian]]'' wrote, "who stole whom off whom is still the subject of some debate and perhaps Ellison's autobiography".[http://observer.guardian.co.uk/osm/story/0,,1786728,00.html Meet the real footballers' wives], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 4 June 2006 Curran and Gerrard married on 16 June 2007, at the [[Cliveden]] House luxury hotel in [[Buckinghamshire]].[https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/topstories/tm_method=full%26objectid=18732839%26siteid=89520-name_page.html Carrick in Wedding Clash], ''[[Daily Mirror]]'', 10 March 2007 They have three daughters and a son.{{cite web|last1=Corless|first1=Liam|title="Our family is complete": Liverpool legend Steven Gerrard confirms wife Alex has given birth to their first son|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/liverpool-legend-steven-gerrard-son-10320064|accessdate=29 April 2017}} On 11 December 2007, while husband Steven Gerrard was away playing with Liverpool, the couple's home was burgled while she and another female resident were inside. Curran was confronted by four masked robbers who were reportedly there for a [[GBP|£]]10,000 watch that Curran had bought for Gerrard for Christmas. On the same day she had mentioned the watch in ''Closer'' magazine. Gerrard was the sixth Liverpool player to be burgled while away playing football.[https://www.theguardian.com/Football/News_Story/0,,2226584,00.html Masked raiders confront Gerrard's wife in sixth raid on Liverpool players' homes], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 13 December 2007 ==Other work== In 2010 Curran took to designing when she launched the Forever Unique by Alex Gerrard Collection {{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1312849/Alex-Gerrard-launches-fashion-range.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | title=It's glam up north: WAGs and soap stars turn out in force at Alex Gerrard's fashion launch | date=17 September 2010}} Her first collection was so successful that she launched a second collection in 2011 http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/film-and-tv/alex-gerrard-the-goal-den-girl-of-style-859195 Curran was revealed as the model for the new 2013 Lipsy VIP Collection.http://www.lipsy.co.uk/blog/1081/party-like-a-lipsy-vip ==Controversy== On 8 August 2006, Curran was arrested on suspicion of assault by [[Merseyside Police]] following a fight at the Shangri-La restaurant in [[Liverpool]] city centre. A teenage girl, also from Maghull, was struck in the face with a glass bottle during the altercation.[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/news/news.html?in_article_id=400143&in_page_id=1770&ico=Homepage&icl=TabModule&icc=picbox&ct=5 Gerrard's WAG arrested over bottle attack], ''[[Daily Mail]]'', 12 August 2006 Curran was released on bail until November 2006,[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/news/news.html?in_article_id=400348&in_page_id=1770 The girl 'hit in the face with a bottle' by Gerrard's fiancee], ''Daily Mail'', 13 August 2006 and the charges were later dropped. Curran was also involved in disagreement with singer [[Jamelia]], who was previously engaged to footballer [[Darren Byfield]]. Jamelia described footballer wives as "leeches", and insulted Curran specifically: "God forbid if Alex Curran split up with Steve Gerrard. Who would she be then?" Curran responded in an interview with ''[[OK!]]'' magazine, "She'll be glad to know I don't know her boyfriend's name but Steven (Gerrard) thinks he's lower than a [[non-league football|non-league]] player."[https://www.theguardian.com/comment/story/0,,1886971,00.html People daily comment section], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 4 October 2006 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110816105613/http://ifdb.co/models/alex_curran/1225 The Internet Fashion Database] * [http://www.alexcurran.net/ Fan site] {{DEFAULTSORT:Curran, Alex}} [[Category:1982 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Aintree]] [[Category:British columnists]] [[Category:Footballers' wives and girlfriends]] [[Category:English female models]]

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Aloha Stadium | nickname = | image = Alohastadium.jpg | image_size = 250 | caption = Looking south in September 2005 | location = [[Halawa, Hawaii]], U.S. | coordinates = {{coord|21.373|N|157.93|W|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=it}} | broke_ground = | opened = September 12, 1975{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lPJLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ae0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4809%2C6048306 |work=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington) |agency=Associated Press |title=Texas A and I crushes Hawaii |date=September 15, 1975 |page=15}}{{cite web|url=http://alohastadium.hawaii.gov/about/trivia/|title=Aloha Stadium – Trivia|publisher=|accessdate=11 July 2016}} | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Hawaii|State of Hawaii]] | operator = Hawaii Stadium Authority | surface = S5 (2011–present)
[[FieldTurf]] (2003–2011){{cite news | url = http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2003/Apr/29/sp/sp04a.html| title = Aloha Stadium surface will be of NFL quality | author = Masuoka, Brandon | work = The Honolulu Advertiser | date = 2003-04-29 | accessdate = 2008-02-04}}
[[AstroTurf]] (1975–2002) | architect = Luckman Partnership, Inc.{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1999/01/28/arts/charles-luckman-architect-who-designed-penn-station-s-replacement-dies-at-89.html | title = Charles Luckman, Architect Who Designed Penn Station's Replacement, Dies at 89 | author = Muschamp, Herbert | work = New York Times | date = 1999-01-28 | accessdate = 2008-02-04}} | dimensions = ''Baseball''
'''Left Field''' – {{convert|325|ft|abbr=on}}
'''Center Field''' – {{convert|420|ft|0|abbr=on}}
'''Right Field''' – {{convert|325|ft|abbr=on}} | tenants = [[Hawaii Rainbow Warriors football]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]])
(1975–present)
[[The Hawaiians (WFL)|The Hawaiians]] ([[World Football League|WFL]]) (1975)
[[Hula Bowl]] (NCAA) (1975–1997, 2006–2008)
[[Hawaii Islanders]] ([[Pacific Coast League|PCL]]) (1976–1987)
[[Team Hawaii]] ([[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|NASL]]) (1977)
[[Aloha Bowl]] (NCAA) (1982–2000)
[[Oahu Bowl]] (NCAA) (1998–2000)
[[Hawaii Bowl|Hawai{{okina}}i Bowl]] (NCAA) (2002–present)
[[St. Louis School|St. Louis Crusaders]] ([[Interscholastic League of Honolulu|ILH]])
[[Pro Bowl]] ([[National Football League|NFL]]) (1980–2009, 2011–2014, 2016) | address = 99–500 Salt Lake Boulevard | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]37 million{{cite news | url = http://starbulletin.com/2006/01/27/news/story03.html | title = Stadium corrosion creates a $129M safety concern | author = Gima, Craig | work = The Honolulu Star-Bulletin | date = 2006-01-27 | accessdate = 2008-02-04}}
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|37000000|1975}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{inflation-fn|US}}) | former_names = | seating_capacity = 50,000{{cite web|url=http://hawaiiathletics.com/sports/2008/5/14/aloha_stadium.aspx?path=football|title=Hawaii Athletics – Aloha Stadium|publisher=|accessdate=11 July 2016}} |}} '''Aloha Stadium''' is a [[stadium]] located in [[Halawa, Hawaii]], a western suburb of [[Honolulu]] (though with a Honolulu address). It is the largest stadium in the state of [[Hawaii]]. Aloha Stadium is home to the [[University of Hawaii at Manoa|University of Hawai{{okina}}i]] [[Hawaii Rainbow Warriors football|Rainbow Warriors]] [[American football|football]] team ([[Mountain West Conference]], [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[NCAA Division I Football Bowl Subdivision|Division I FBS]]). It hosts the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]'s [[Hawai'i Bowl]], and formerly was home to the [[National Football League]]'s [[Pro Bowl]] from 1980 through 2016 (except in 2010 and 2015) and to the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]'s [[Hula Bowl]] from 1975 to 1997 and again from 2006 to 2008. It also hosts numerous high school football games during the season, and serves as a venue for large concerts and events. A [[flea market|swap meet]] in the stadium's parking lot every Wednesday, Saturday and Sunday draws large crowds.{{cite web|url=http://www.alohastadiumswapmeet.net/Contents/AboutUs.asp |title=Hawaii's premier Aloha Stadium Swap Meet an Outdoor Market in Hawaii|Aloha Outdoor Market, Flea Markets and Swap meet for shopping in Honolulu |publisher=Alohastadiumswapmeet.net |date=1975-09-12 |accessdate=2009-07-16 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090531123144/http://alohastadiumswapmeet.net/Contents/AboutUs.asp |archivedate=31 May 2009 |deadurl=yes }} Aloha Stadium was home field for the [[AAA (baseball)|AAA]] [[Hawaii Islanders]] of the [[Pacific Coast League]] (PCL) from 1975 to 1987, before the [[Colorado Springs Sky Sox|team]] moved to [[Colorado Springs, Colorado|Colorado Springs]]. ==History== [[File:AlohastadiumsatUSGS.png|thumb|left|Aerial view in baseball/soccer configuration]] Before 1975, Honolulu's main outdoor stadium had been [[Honolulu Stadium]], a wooden stadium on King Street. However, it had reached the end of its useful life by the 1960s, and was well below the standards for Triple-A baseball. The need for a new stadium was hastened by the Rainbows' move to NCAA Division I. Located west of downtown Honolulu and two miles north of [[Honolulu International Airport]], Aloha Stadium was constructed in 1975 at a cost of $37 million. The baseball field is aligned north-northwest (home plate to centerfield), as is the football field. The first sporting event at Aloha Stadium was a college football game between Hawaii and [[Texas A&M–Kingsville Javelinas football|Texas A&I]] (now Texas A&M-Kingsville) on September 13, 1975. Played on Saturday night, the crowd was 32,247,[http://www.alohastadiumswapmeet.net/Contents/AboutUs.asp Aloha Stadium Swap Meet "About Us" page] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090531123144/http://alohastadiumswapmeet.net/Contents/AboutUs.asp |date=2009-05-31 }}, [http://www.alohastadiumswapmeet.net/ alohastadiumswapmeet.net] and the visitors prevailed, {{nowrap|43–9.}} The stadium was somewhat problematic for its initial primary tenant, the baseball Islanders. Located in west-central Oahu, it was far from the team's fan base, and many were unwilling to make the drive. Additionally, while [[TheBus (Honolulu)|TheBus]] stopped at the main gate of Honolulu Stadium, the stop for Aloha Stadium was located some distance from the gate. As a result, attendance plummeted and never really recovered—a major factor in the franchise's ultimate move to the mainland.Kaneshiro, Stacy. [http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2009/Jul/04/sp/hawaii907040333.html "Islanders a fan hit during 27-year run"]. ''[[The Honolulu Advertiser]]'', 2009-07-04. Additionally, stadium management initially refused to allow the use of [[Cleat (shoe)#Baseball|metal spikes]] on the [[AstroTurf]] in May 1976. When the [[Tacoma Rainiers|Tacoma Twins]] complied with a parent-club directive to wear the spikes, stadium management turned off the center field lights. After 35 minutes, the umpires forfeited the game to the Twins. The Islanders protested, claiming they had no control over the lights. However, the PCL sided with the Twins, citing a league rule that the home team is responsible for providing acceptable playing facilities.Stewart, Chuck. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1338&dat=19760901&id=KfpLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1vgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4981,314263 Sport Stew]. Spokane Daily Chronicle, 1976-09-01. The teams ended the season in a tie for first in the Western Division and Hawaii won the one-game playoff in Tacoma. As originally built, Aloha Stadium had various configurations for different sport venues and other purposes. Four movable 7,000-seat sections, each 3.5 million {{nowrap|pounds}} could move using [[air caster]]s into a diamond configuration for baseball (also used for soccer), an oval for football, or a triangle for concerts. In January 2007, the stadium was permanently locked into its football configuration due to cost and maintenance issues.{{cite news | url = http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2006/Jul/28/sp/FP607280343.html | title = Aloha Stadium losing baseball configuration | author = Masuoka, Brandon | work = The Honolulu Advertiser | date = 2006-07-28 | accessdate = 2008-02-04| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080120210620/http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2006/Jul/28/sp/FP607280343.html| archivedate= 20 January 2008 | deadurl= no}} An engineer from Rolair Systems, the NASA spin-off company that engineered the system,{{cite web|url=http://spinoff.nasa.gov/spinoff/spinitem?title=Convertible+Stadium|title=Convertible Stadium|accessdate=August 9, 2012|publisher=NASA}} claims that the problem was caused by a concrete contractor that ignored specifications for the concrete pads under the stadium.{{cite journal|last=Kieding|first=Bob|title=Moving Seats|journal=Popular Science|publisher=Wright's Media|pages=8|year=2012|issue=October}} There have been numerous discussions with Hawaii lawmakers who are concerned with the physical condition of the stadium. There are several issues regarding rusting of the facility, several hundred seats that need to be replaced, and restroom facilities that need to be expanded to accommodate more patrons. Much of the rust is due to a design mistake in the choice of [[weathering steel]] to build the stadium. It was intended to create a protective patina that would eliminate the need for painting, but in the ocean salt-laden air of Honolulu, it has never stopped rusting. A 2005 study by Honolulu engineering firm [[Wiss, Janney, Elstner Associates, Inc.]] determined that the stadium required $99 million to be completely restored and an additional $115 million for ongoing maintenance and refurbishment over the next 20 years to extend its useful life.{{cite web|url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2007/May/11/ln/FP705110373.html |title=Stadium rust to get $12.4M treatment|publisher=The Honolulu Advertiser |date=2007-05-11 |accessdate=2009-07-16}} In early 2007, the state legislature proposed to spend $300 million to build a new facility as opposed to spending approximately $216 million to extend the life of Aloha Stadium for another {{nowrap|20–30}} years. The new stadium may also be used to attempt to lure a [[Super Bowl]] to Hawaii in the future.{{cite news | url = http://starbulletin.com/2006/04/03/sports/story01.html | title = Super Dreams: Bringing the 50th Super Bowl to the 50th state would be costly | author = Reardon, Dave | work = The Honolulu Star-Bulletin | date = 2006-04-03 | accessdate = 2008-02-04}} One council member has said that if immediate repairs are not made within the next seven years, then the stadium will probably have to be demolished due to safety concerns. In May 2007, the state allotted $12.4 million to be used towards removing corrosion and rust from the structure.{{cite news | url = http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2007/May/11/ln/FP705110373.html | title = Stadium rust to get $12.4M treatment | author = Arakawa, Lynda | work = The Honolulu Advertiser | date = 2007-05-11 | accessdate = 2008-02-04}} ==Expansion and improvements== In 2003, the stadium surface was changed from [[AstroTurf]] (which had been in place since the stadium opened) to [[FieldTurf]]. In July 2011 the field was replaced with an [[Act Global]] UBU Sports Speed S5-M synthetic turf system. In 2008, the state of Hawaii approved the bill of $185 million to refurbish the aging Aloha Stadium.{{cite news|title=Hawaii stadium to get $185M overhaul; UH expands pay-per-view package |first=Brandon |last=Masuoka |url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2008/Jun/27/ln/hawaii806270385.html |newspaper=[[Honolulu Advertiser]] |issn=1072-7191 |oclc=8807414 |date=2008-06-27 |accessdate=2013-02-04 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ECDDmB5u?url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2008/Jun/27/ln/hawaii806270385.html |archivedate=2013-02-05 |deadurl=no |df= }} In 2010, Aloha Stadium completely retrofitted its scoreboard and video screen to be more up to date with its high definition capability. The Aloha Stadium Authority plans to add more luxury suites, replacing all seats, rusting treatments, parking lots, more restrooms, pedestrian bridge supports, enclosed lounge, and more. There is also a proposal that would close the 4 openings in the corners of the stadium to add more seats. In 2011, the playing field was refurbished in part due to a naming rights sponsorship from Hawaiian Airlines. As a result of the sponsorship deal, the field was referred to as Hawaiian Airlines Field at Aloha Stadium.[http://sponsorpitch.com/articles/2496 Hawaiian Airlines Grabs Naming Rights To Aloha Stadium Field; SponsorPitch; 08-04-2011] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111117190626/http://sponsorpitch.com/articles/2496 |date=2011-11-17 }} The airline did not renew sponsorship after the deal expired in 2016. As a result, the field went unnamed until late August, when [[Hawaiian Tel Federal Credit Union]] signed a 3-year/$275,000 agreement. As of 2016, the field is now known as '''Hawaiian Tel Federal Credit Union Field at Aloha Stadium'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/business/business-breaking/credit-union-buys-naming-rights-for-aloha-stadium-field/|title=Credit union buys naming rights for Aloha Stadium field|date=26 August 2016|work=staradvertiser.com|accessdate=26 August 2016}} In early 2017, there was a study in the Honolulu StarAdvertiser about replacing Aloha Stadium due to safety concerns and a liability risk. The plan is to build a smaller 30,000 seat stadium on the existing property and also build commercial development around the stadium. In theory, it would save the state millions of dollars instead of renovating and keep the existing stadium as it is.{{cite web|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/2014/06/26/sports/study-recommends-smaller-venue-to-replace-aloha-stadium/|title=Study recommends smaller venue to replace Aloha Stadium|work=staradvertiser.com|accessdate=August 8, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/2017/04/05/sports/sports-breaking/report-aloha-stadium-a-potential-danger-to-public/|title=Report: Aloha Stadium now a 'liability,' cheaper to build new stadium|work=staradvertiser.com|accessdate=August 8, 2018}} ==Events== [[File:US Navy 070210-N-4965F-001 A joint service color guard parades the colors at mid-field during the National Football League^rsquo,s 2007 Pro Bowl game at Aloha Stadium in Honolulu, Hawaii.jpg|thumb|right|A joint service color guard parades the colors at mid-field during the 2007 Pro Bowl game]] ===Baseball=== In {{mlby|1997}}, a three-game regular season series between [[Major League Baseball]]'s [[St. Louis Cardinals]] and [[San Diego Padres]] was held at the stadium.{{cite news | url = http://starbulletin.com/97/02/25/sports/story1.html | title = Padres, Cardinals to play in Hawaii |author1=Arnett, Paul |author2=Yuen, Mike | work = The Honolulu Star-Bulletin | date = 1997-02-25 | accessdate = 2008-02-04}} The series was played as a [[Doubleheader (baseball)|doubleheader]] on April 19 and a nationally broadcast ([[ESPN]]) game on April 20. In 1975, the Padres had played an exhibition series against the [[Seibu Lions]] of Japan's [[Pacific League]]. ===Soccer=== Aloha Stadium hosted the [[Pan-Pacific Championship 2008|inaugural]] [[Pan-Pacific Championship]] (February 20–23, 2008), a knockout soccer tournament, involving four teams from Japan's [[J-League]], North America's [[Major League Soccer]] (MLS) and Australia/New Zealand's [[A-League]].{{cite news | url = http://www.merinews.com/catFull.jsp?articleID=128203 | title = 2008 Pan-Pacific Championship: Make it more inclusive | author = Carlos Alvarez-Galloso, Roberto | publisher = MeriNews | date = 2007-12-26 | accessdate = 2008-02-04}} The [[2012 Hawaiian Islands Invitational]] was also held at the venue. The [[United States women's national soccer team]] was scheduled play a game against Trinidad and Tobago as part of their World Cup Winning Victory Tour at the stadium on December 6, 2015; however, the game was canceled the day before gameday due to concerns over the turf being unsafe to play on.{{cite web|title=U.S. Soccer Cancels Dec. 6 Match against T&T in Hawaii Due to Field Conditions|url=http://www.ussoccer.com/stories/2015/12/06/09/55/151205-wntvtri-honolulu-cancelled|website=US Soccer|accessdate=7 December 2015}} ===Rugby=== On June 2, 2013, the stadium played host to a [[rugby league]] test match where [[Samoa national rugby league team|Samoa]] defeated the [[United States national rugby league team|USA]] 34–10.{{cite web|url=http://www.khon2.com/news/local-news/tomahawks-get-ready-for-match-up-with-na-toa-samoa-at-aloha-stadium|title=Tomahawks get ready for match-up with Na Toa Samoa at Aloha Stadium|work=KHON2|accessdate=6 January 2015}} In June, the [[Brisbane Broncos]] from the Australasian-based [[National Rugby League]] (NRL) competition organized for a rugby league match to be played at Aloha Stadium against NRL rivals [[Penrith Panthers]] later in 2015.{{cite web|title=Broncos Panthers To Play Match In Hawaii|url=http://www.triplem.com.au/sydney/sport/nrl/news/2015/6/brisbane-broncos-penrith-panthers-exhibition-match-aloha-stadium-hawaii-2015/|website=triplem.com.au|accessdate=27 March 2016}} However, in September the NRL blocked the idea and the game didn't go ahead.{{cite web|title=Exhibition matches are a bad idea in the USA – just look at the Wallabies!|url=http://www.theroar.com.au/2015/09/17/exhibition-matches-bad-idea-usa-just-look-wallabies/|website=theroar.com.au|accessdate=27 March 2016}} ===Graduation ceremonies=== Aloha Stadium is also the venue for five public high school graduation ceremonies. [[Admiral Arthur W. Radford High School|Radford High School]], [[Mililani High School]], [[Aiea High School]], [[James Campbell High School]], and [[Pearl City High School (Hawaii)|Pearl City High School]] held their 2016 graduation ceremonies at the stadium in early June. === Concerts === {| class="wikitable" style=font-size:100% style="text-align:center" |- ! width=12% style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Hawaii Rainbow Warriors|color=white}};|Date ! width=10% style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Hawaii Rainbow Warriors|color=white}};|Artist ! width=10% style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Hawaii Rainbow Warriors|color=white}};|Opening act(s) ! width=16% style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Hawaii Rainbow Warriors|color=white}};|Tour / Concert name ! width=10% style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Hawaii Rainbow Warriors|color=white}};|Attendance ! width=10% style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Hawaii Rainbow Warriors|color=white}};|Revenue ! width=20% style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Hawaii Rainbow Warriors|color=white}};|Notes |- | February 25, 1984 || [[The Police]] || — || [[Synchronicity Tour]] || — || — || |- | November 6, 1995 || [[The Eagles]] || — || [[Hell Freezes Over Tour]] || — || — || |- | January 3, 1997 || rowspan=2|[[Michael Jackson]] || rowspan=2|— || rowspan=2|[[HIStory World Tour]] || 35,000 || rowspan=2|— || rowspan=2|These were his only US shows that decade. Also, the first person to sell out the stadium.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KH0hAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nIoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6129%2C1155602 |work=Spartanburg Herald-Journal |location=(South Carolina) |title=King of Pop ends Hawaiian tour|date=January 7, 1997 |page=A2}} |- | January 4, 1997 || 35,000 |- | May 3, 1997 || [[Gloria Estefan]] || — || [[Evolution World Tour]] || — || — || |- | May 29, 1997 || [[Whitney Houston]] || [[Bobby Brown]] || [[Pacific Rim Tour]] || 29,118 / 29,118 || $1,634,370 || Bobby Brown opened up the show singing his hit tunes. [[File:Franz Heinrich 001.jpg|thumb|330x330px| The Billiard Room at Schönbrunn Palace, c. 1855/1860, [[Chromolithography|chromolithograph]] after a watercolour by Franz Heinrich ]] A '''billiard room''' (also '''billiards room''', or more specifically '''pool room''', '''snooker room''') is a [[recreation room]], such as in a house or recreation center, with a [[Billiards table|billiards, pool or snooker table]]. The term billiard room is sometimes also used as [[synonym]]ous with "[[billiard hall]]" i.e., a business providing public access to hourly-rental or coin-operated billiard tables.
The billiard room may be in the public center of the house or the private areas of the house.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_zAEAAAAMBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Old House Interiors|last=Publications|first=Home Buyer|date=2016-11-29|publisher=Home Buyer Publications|language=en}}</ref>
Billiard rooms require proper lighting and clearances for game playing.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b2wHBAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Interior Design Productivity Toolbox: Checklists and Best Practices to Manage Your Workflow|last=Harbinger|first=Phyllis|date=2014-08-04|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9781118680438|language=en}}</ref> Although there are adjustable cue sticks on the market, 5 feet of clearance around the pool table is ideal.<ref name=":0" />
Interior designer [[Charlotte Moss]] believed that "a billiard room is synonymous with group dynamics. It's where you mix drinks and embark on a little friendly competition..."<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7PYPa1Kb31UC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Charlotte Moss Decorates: The Art of Creating Elegant and Inspired Rooms|last=Moss|first=Charlotte|date=2011-01-01|publisher=Random House Incorporated|isbn=9780847833696|language=en}}</ref>
== History == Billiards probably developed from one of the late-14th century or early-15th century lawn games in which players hit balls with sticks.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q8NMAgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Encyclopedia of World Sport: From Ancient Times to the Present|last=Levinson|first=David|last2=Christensen|first2=Karen|date=1999-01-01|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195131956|language=en}}</ref> The earliest mention of pool as an indoor table game is in a 1470 inventory list of the accounts of King Louis XI of France.<ref name=":1" />
Following the [[French Revolution]] and the Napoleonic Wars, billiard rooms were added to some famous 18th-century cafés in Paris and other cities.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MlKhCAAAQBAJ&pg=PT165&dq=billiard+room+interior+design&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjpgrDwxM3QAhWFJiYKHa5PBZgQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=billiard%20room%20interior%20design&f=false|title=Encyclopedia of Interior Design|last=Banham|first=Joanna|date=1997-05-01|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781136787584|language=en}}</ref> [[File:Billiard Room - Mark Twain House.tiff|thumb|Billiard Room - Mark Twain House]] Although billiards had long been enjoyed by both men and women, a trend towards male suites developed in 19th century Great Britain. These male suites paired billiard rooms with smoking rooms and sometimes libraries. One example of these male suites is Castle Carr near Halifax.<ref name=":2" /> By the turn of the century, billiard rooms were considered a standard feature in great British houses with ''[[House Beautiful]]'' claiming "Up-to-date owners of English estates have installed billiard rooms..."<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9dtNAQAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=House Beautiful|date=1908-01-01|publisher=Hearst Corporation|language=en}}</ref>
Many mid- and late-19th century billiard rooms were designed in an Oriental or Moorish style.<ref name=":2" /> Mark Twain's billiard room in Hartford, CT was decorated with quasi-Moorish stencils.<ref name=":2" />
The late 19th and early 20th century represent the billiard room's heyday.<ref name=":2" />
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{coord|51.918|-2.067|display=title|region:GB_scale:5000}} The '''Steeplechasing Hall of Fame''' is a museum at Prestbury Park, in the village of [[Prestbury, Gloucestershire]]. Opened in 1994 at [[Cheltenham Racecourse]], the [[Hall of Fame]] charts [[Steeplechase (horse racing)|steeplechasing]] history from 1819 and showcases the sport's riders and trainers associated with [[National Hunt racing]].
==Members== [[Michael W. Dickinson]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.breederscup.com/bio.aspx?id%3D2279 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-05-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101214111250/http://breederscup.com/bio.aspx?id=2279 |archivedate=2010-12-14 |df= }} Breeders Cup</ref><ref>http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/horse/columns/story?id=1221033 ESPN</ref>
[[Dick Francis]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * [https://books.google.com/books?id=QMFDJfYT2UEC&pg=PA72&lpg=PA72&dq=Steeplechasing+Hall+of+Fame,+dickinson&source=bl&ots=S7LltN1fmS&sig=sU6NStBVQMnIz4Fif_STkXEYaG4&hl=en&ei=MD-lStFe0-OcB7bXmaQF&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7#v=onepage&q=Steeplechasing%20Hall%20of%20Fame%2C%20dickinson&f=false The ''Encyclopedia of British Horseracing'' by Wray Vamplew, Joyce Kay]
{{Horseracing-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | name = Burnley Greyhound Stadium | nickname = | image = | location = [[Burnley]], [[Lancashire]] | coordinates = 53°46'53.6"N 2°13'33.1"W | opened = 1927 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 1935 | owner = | operator = | surface = }}
'''Burnley Greyhound Stadium''' also known as '''Towneley Stadium''' was a former [[greyhound racing]] and [[Motorcycle speedway|speedway]] stadium in [[Burnley]], [[Lancashire]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Barnes|first=Julia|title=Daily Mirror Greyhound Fact File|page =410|year=1988|publisher=Ringpress Books|isbn=0-948955-15-5}}</ref>
==Origins and Opening== South of Burnley there was a large open space known as [[Towneley Park]] which served Towneley Hall and the Towneley family for five centuries. In 1902 the estate was sold to the Burnley Corporation and despite the fact that most of the park remained in situ they did agree the sale of a plot of land that ran alongside the River Calder and the Hall's north access road. This ten acre plot was in the area known as Towneley Holmes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.burnley.gov.uk/residents/towneley-hall|title=Towneley Hall|publisher=Burnley gov.uk}}</ref>
The stadium could be accessed from either the east or west side, on the east side the path was opposite the Smalley Street junction with Woodgrove Road and cut across Towneley Park meeting the Hall's north access road. The stadium kennels were adjacent to this path situated on the north side of the stadium. From the west there was footbridge over the [[River Calder, Lancashire|River Calder]] that met the Hall's north access road. Whichever entry was chosen resulted in the same turnstile entrances on the east side of the stadium being used where the main stand overlooked the course.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.old-maps.co.uk/#/Map/385215/431714/12/101104|title=OS County Series Lancashire and Furness 1931|publisher=old-maps.co.uk}}</ref>
A local company with a share capital of £13,000 purchased and constructed the greyhound track which was a very large 570 yards in circumference. The first race night was held on 3 September 1927 with seven thousand attending the meeting opened by Lady O’Hagan.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pictures of Burnley's Greyhound Racing Track at Towneley Holmes. 27 August|year=1927|newspaper=Express and Advertiser}}</ref>
==History== The greyhounds initially housed at the Burnley track consisted of 100 brought mainly from Hull. The stadium came under the control of a company called the Associated Greyhound Racecourses with Towneley becoming their second of three tracks that they would eventually own. The first being [[Darnall Stadium]] and the third was the [[Old Craven Park]] in Hull. Towneley also hosted dirt track speedway in 1929.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greyhoundderby.com/Burnley%20speedway.html|title=Burnley Speedway|publisher=Greyhound Derby.com}}</ref>
Haulage businessman Bill Sharples had a litter out of track bitch Calliope, sired by [[Grand National (greyhounds)|Grand National]] finalist Douro and trainers included [[Jack Hillman]] (a former England goalkeeper) and Jack Ashworth. In 1931 just four years after opening the Associated Greyhound Racecourses went bankrupt with the track then being taken over by a local businessman named W Spencer who closed the stadium blaming the government betting bill that restricted the days that tracks could race. With meetings limited to a maximum of 101 per annum the management put the stadium, kennels and equipment up for auction.<ref>{{cite news|title=Burnley Greyhound stadium. 6 November|year=1935|newspaper=Burnley Express}}</ref>
==Closure== During 1935 the stadium was taken over by Captain Ramsbottom who had replaced Harry Bury as the judge and handicapper under a previous promotion. Ramsbottom then made a quick profit by selling onto two brothers Dr. and Clem Hodgson with the last greyhound meeting taking place on 2 November 1935. The buildings associated to the stadium (stands, shelters and kennels) were demolished and the track was filled in as the site became playing fields.<ref>{{cite news|title=Burnley Greyhound stadium. 9 November|year=1935|newspaper=Burnley Express}}</ref>
A golf course then spread its wings north and incorporated the site into the course. The position of the stadium today would have been on the northerly holes of a golf course, exactly on the opposite side of the River Calder to the £33 million [[Unity College, Burnley|Unity College]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{English greyhound tracks}}

revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=October 2015}}
'''Canine hydrotherapy''' is a form of [[hydrotherapy]] directed at the treatment of [[chronic (medicine)|chronic]] conditions, post-operative recovery, and pre-operative or general fitness in [[dog]]s.
==Background== [[Image:Bilateral hip dysplasia.JPG|left|thumb|Hip dysplasia may be helped by hydrotherapy.]] A number of conditions in dogs may be aggravated by or may show slow or no improvement as a result of [[weight bearing]] exercise. Among these are [[Hip dysplasia (canine)|hip dysplasia]] and [[Osteochondritis|osteochondritis dissecans]] (OCD), conditions most common in medium to large purebred dogs, such as [[German Shepherd]]s, [[Labrador|Labrador Retriever]]s or [[Golden Retriever]]s; [[Canine degenerative myelopathy|chronic degenerative radiculomyelopathy]] (CDRM), a degenerative disease of the spinal cord which causes hind limb problems in German Shepherds; and [[luxating patella]] which is seen predominantly in small and [[toy dog|toy breeds]].
Injuries to the [[cruciate ligament]] or other [[ligament]]s may make post-operative weight-bearing exercise in dogs problematic. [[Obesity in pets|Obese dogs]], while requiring exercise, may aggravate existing conditions or injure themselves due to the weight exerted on their joints if walked normally.
==History== [[Hydrotherapy]] for humans has been used since ancient times, and some attempt at formalizing treatment was made during the 18th century. Similarly, the benefits of sea water for the treatment and prevention of leg injuries in [[horse]]s has been known for centuries. Because of the financial benefits surrounding the treatment of [[horse racing|race horses]], around the mid-19th century inventors began to produce devices to replicate the benefits of cold sea water immersion for horses.
The [[greyhound racing]] industry eventually recognized the benefits of the equine treatment and in the UK was brought to the forefront by a specialized canine hydrotherapy pool. From there, the therapy was extended to dogs in general. This had led to the development of underwater treadmills to relieve stress on the animals joints whilst building strength. These have been a turning point in the rehabilitation of dogs as they can be placed in smaller areas, but offer a controlled treatment.
==Pool design== Pool designs for canine hydrotherapy vary, but most have generic elements. The pool tends to be smaller than a human [[swimming pool]] and is heated. (This is unlike equine hydrotherapy pools. Horses generate a lot of body heat when swimming, so equine pools use cold water to prevent the animal overheating.) A dog's muscles benefit from the warming effects of the heated water. Most pools have a ramp for entry and exit and some have [[dog harness|harness]]es to maintain the dog in position in the water. There may be a manual or electric [[hoist (device)|hoist]] for lifting dogs in and out of the water. Water is [[Water chlorination|chlorinated]] or treated with an alternative chemical. Some have [[Jet (fluid)|jet]]s to add resistance and make the dog swim more strongly.
==Uses== As an alternative or complement to weight-bearing exercise and medication, canine hydrotherapy may speed recovery after operations or slow the progression of degenerative conditions. It may be used as a pre-operative fitness regime to allow a dog to maintain condition before an operation if it can not exercise normally. When a [[congenital disorder|congenital condition]] is identified in a puppy, it may be the case that surgery is not possible until the animal is physically mature; during the period preceding the surgery, hydrotherapy can be employed to maintain the dog's condition.
Spinal injuries or surgery can cause impairment of motor function, which may be treated by allowing the dog to exercise in water; it provides support and allows the dog to exercise its muscles while nerve regeneration is taking place. Degenerative conditions can make normal weight bearing exercise difficult and pressure on joints and limbs may aggravate some conditions, so hydrotherapy can be used in these cases to allow the dog to exercise in an environment where there is no pressure on the affected areas.
Obese dogs can build fitness and lose weight as a result of exercise in a hydrotherapy pool without putting excessive weight on their joints. Hydrotherapy may be used as part of a general fitness routine for dogs.
==References== {{Reflist}}
===Bibliography=== *{{cite web|url=http://www.canine-hydrotherapy.org//|title=The Canine Hydrotherapy Association|accessdate=1 November 2010}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.mascottshydrotherapy.com/ailments.htm|title=Ailments Guide|publisher=Mascotts Hydrotherapy|accessdate=18 December 2006}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.meadow-farm.com/treatment.htm|title=Therapy|publisher=Meadow Farm Hydrotherapy|date=2004|accessdate=18 December 2006}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.equinenaturaltherapy.com/equine_hydrotherapy.htm|title=Equine Cold Water Therapy|publisher=Centre for Equine Therapy|date=2004|accessdate=18 December 2006}} *{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia =Encyclopædia Britannica|title = Hydrotherapy| publisher = Cambridge University Press| location = London| edition = 11th| date = 1911}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/gloucestershire/content/articles/2007/09/20/doggie_paddle_feature.shtml|title=BBC Gloucestershire: Canine Hydrotherapy|publisher=BBC Gloucestershire|date=2007|accessdate=24 September 2007}}
[[Category:Dog health|Hydrotherapy]] [[Category:Hydrotherapy]]

{{Infobox football club | clubname = Deportivo Mictlán | image = Deportivo Mictlan.png | image_size = 200px | fullname = Club Deportivo Mictlán | nickname = ''Los Conejos'' (The Rabbits) | founded = | ground = [[Estadio La Asunción]]
[[Asunción Mita]], Guatemala | capacity = 3,000 | chairman = Erlin Armando Palma | manager = Sergio Guevarahttps://lared.com.gt/sergio-guevara-renuncio-dt-mictlan/ | league = [[Liga Nacional de Guatemala]] | season = Apertura 2010 | position = | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=|pattern_ra1= | leftarm1=FFFFFF|body1=FFFFFF|rightarm1=FFFFFF|shorts1=FFFFFF|socks1=FFFFFF | pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2= | leftarm2=000099|body2=000099|rightarm2=000099|shorts2=000099|socks2=000099| }} '''Deportivo Mictlán''' is a Guatemalan [[association football|football]] club, playing in the top division again in the 2010 Clausura tournament. Nicknamed ''Los Conejos'' (the Rabbits) and based in [[Asunción Mita]], [[Jutiapa (department)|Jutiapa]], their home stadium is [[Estadio La Asunción]], which holds 3,000.[http://www.worldstadiums.com/middle_america/countries/guatemala.shtml Stadiums in Guatemala] – World Stadiums ==History== Mictlán was promoted for the first time in 1992 when they bought the license that ''Galcasa'' from [[Villa Nueva, Guatemala|Villa Nueva]] left in the top division. In 2006 Mictlán achieved their second promotion to the [[Liga Nacional de Guatemala|Liga Nacional]] when they defeated Xinabajul in [[Primera División de Ascenso]] extra match,[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesg/guat06.html Guatemala 2005/06] – RSSSF playing the 2006–2007 season in ''Liga Nacional'' for the first time since 1996. They would be back in the Second Division soon again after finishing last in the overall standings, thus being automatically demoted and stay there through the 2009–2010 season . The team returned to Guatemala's top division for the 2010 Clausura tournament after defeating Sacachispas 1–0 in overtime. ===First-team squad=== {{Fs start|nat=|pos=|other=|no=|name=}} {{Fs player|no=—|nat=Mexico|name=[[Rafael Murguía]]|pos=FW}} {{Fs end}} ==Current Coaching Staff== *''As of December 1, 2012''. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Position !! Nationality !! Name |- | Manager || {{Flag|Chile}} || Sergio Pardo |- | Fitness Coach || {{Flag|Uruguay}} ||Pablo Vega |} ==Board of directors== *''As of June 25, 2010''.[http://www.guatefutbol.com/index.php/gf/17-mal-mar-mic/4416-re-estructuran-directiva Re-estructuran Directiva de Mictlán] «Consultado el 25 de junio de 2010» {| class="wikitable" |- ! Position !! Name |- | President || Erlin Armando Palma |- | Deputy President || Armando Brindis |- | Deputy President || Manuel Armando Rodríguez |- | Deputy President || Rubén Arturo Rodríguez |- | Secretary || Álvaro Tobar |- | Treasurer || Fredy Corado |} ==Club Statistics and Records== *'''Biggest win achieved''': 6–1 to [[Juventud Retalteca]] (1993–94 League). *'''Embedded biggest win''': 6–1 from [[Comunicaciones]] (1994–95 League). *'''Best League position''': 3rd. (1995) *'''Top scorer''': Rudy Rolando Ramírez (18 goals) ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Guatemalan Liga Mayor}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Deportivo Mictlan}} [[Category:Football clubs in Guatemala|Mictlan]] {{Guatemala-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | name = Duchère Stadium | image = La Duchère - 111 - 09mai2015.jpg | caption = Exterior View of the Stadium. | address = 270, avenue [[Andreï Sakharov|Andreï-Sakharov]]
69009 Lyon | coordinates = {{coord|45.7879|4.7976|type:landmark|display=inline}} | built = 1966 | owners = Ville de [[Lyon]] | tenants =[[:fr:Association sportive Lyon-Duchère|AS Lyon-Duchère]]
[[:fr:Rink hockey club de Lyon]] | capacity= [[Football]] : 5438 places{{Cite book | author1 = Guy Borgé | title = Lyon: passé et présent sous le même angle | editor = Champion | year = 1987 | page = 72 | isbn = 9782051008709 |others = Crispini(illustrator) }}. | pushpin_map = France }} The '''stadium Duchère''' or '''Balmont stadium''' or the''' stadium-Balmont Duchère''', is a [[Stadium]] located in the [[9th arrondissement of Lyon]] in the neighborhood [[:fr:La Duchère|La Duchère]]. Third in the Lyon area by its capacity (after [[Stade de Gerland|Stade Gerland]] and [[Matmut Stadium]]), It hosts multiple disciplines: [[Association football|football]], [[Sport of athletics|athletics]], [[Rugby union|Rugby Union]], [[Rugby league|Rugby League]], and [[American football|American Football]], etc. Since autumn 2000, roller skaters can benefit from a speed ring of 400 meters. This is the stadium of the football club of [[AS Lyon-Duchère]] (football) and the [[:fr:Rink hockey club de Lyon|Rink hockey club de Lyon]]. Since 2012, the [[Stephane-Diagana Athletic Hall]] is located nearby. == History == [[File:La Duchère - 35 - 09mai2015.jpg|left|thumb|The main stand, the track and the football field.]] The opening of the stadium took place in 1966{{Cite web|url = http://www.info-stades.fr/stade/616/lyon-stade-de-balmont|title = Stade de la Duchère - Lyon}}. on the site of the former [[Fort de la Duchere|Fort Duchère]]. In 2013, the athletics track was upgraded; the new track, upgraded at a cost of 1.75 million euros, was inaugurated in presence of the discus thrower [[Mélina Robert-Michon|Robert-Michon Melina]]{{Cite web|url = http://www.lyon-info.fr/?Duchere-le-stade-de-Balmont-se-met|title = Duchère : le stade de Balmont aux normes interrégionales|date = 26 September 2013|author = Michael Augustin}}.{{Cite web|url = http://radioparilly.20minutes-blogs.fr/archive/2013/09/29/temp-23a98b3523f44de08f720d4d377259f3-882615.html|title = La piste du stade Balmont de La Duchère inaugurée|date = 29 September 2013}}. == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:9th arrondissement of Lyon]] [[Category:Football venues in France]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1966]]
