{{about|Gilmore Stadium|the stadium of a similar name in Los Angeles|Gilmore Field}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name= Gilmore Stadium | nickname= | image= | image_size= | location= Los Angeles, California | broke_ground= | opened= 1934 | renovated= | expanded= | closed= | demolished= 1952 | owner= | operator= | surface= Grass | construction_cost= | architect= | former_names= | tenants=[[Hollywood Stars]] (baseball) (1939)
[[Los Angeles Bulldogs]] (football) (1940–1947)
[[Los Angeles Mustangs]] (football) (1943–1944)
[[Loyola Marymount Lions football|Loyola Marymount Lions]] (football)
[[Pepperdine Waves football|Pepperdine Waves]] (football) | seating_capacity= 18,000 | dimensions= }} '''Gilmore Stadium''' was a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]]. It was opened in May 1934 and demolished in 1952, when the land was used to build [[CBS Television City]]. The stadium held 18,000. It was located next to [[Gilmore Field]]. The stadium was located west of Curson Avenue, surrounded by Beverly Boulevard, Fairfax Avenue and Third Street. The stadium was built by Earl Gilmore, son of [[Arthur F. Gilmore]] and president of A. F. Gilmore Oil, a California-based petroleum company which was developed after Arthur struck oil on the family property.{{Cite web | url = http://www.projectballpark.org/history/pcl/gilmore.html| title= Gilmore Field| publisher=Project Ballpark| accessdate=January 11, 2014}} The area was rich in petroleum, which was the source of the "tar" in the nearby [[La Brea Tar Pits]]. ==Uses== ===Football venue=== It was used for [[American football]] games at both the professional and collegiate level. The stadium was the home of the [[Los Angeles Bulldogs]], the first professional football team in Los Angeles.[http://www.farmersmarketla.com/history/marketfacts.html The history of Farmer's Market], Retrieved June 22, 2007 The Bulldogs competed as an independent team before joining the [[American Football League (1936)|second American Football League]] in 1937 and winning its championship with a perfect 8–0–0 record, the first professional football team to win its championship with an unblemished record.Bob Carroll, Michael Gershman, David Neft, and John Thorn, ''Total Football II: The Official Encyclopedia of the National Football League'' (HarperCollins 1999) {{ISBN|0-06-039232-0}} After the collapse of the league, the Bulldogs returned to being an independent team before joining the [[American Football League (1938)|American Professional Football Association]] in 1939. The Bulldogs then became charter members of the [[Pacific Coast Professional Football League]] in 1940{{cite web|title=Kenosha Cardinals: Life on the Fringe (1983)|url=http://arenafootball.tribe.net/thread/e4a30ad4-1389-477f-ad61-3cd9612d9ae3|website=arenafootball.tribe.net|accessdate=17 October 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060301034353/http://arenafootball.tribe.net/thread/e4a30ad4-1389-477f-ad61-3cd9612d9ae3|archivedate=March 1, 2006}} and played in Gilmore Stadium until 1948, when the team moved to [[Long Beach, California]], for its (and the league's) final season. The stadium was also home to another professional football teams, the [[Los Angeles Mustangs]] of the Pacific Coast Professional Football League. Gilmore Stadium was the site of two 1940 [[National Football League]] (NFL) [[Pro Bowl]]s. The stadium was home to the collegiate [[Loyola Marymount Lions football|Loyola Marymount Lions football team]] and [[Pepperdine Waves football|Pepperdine Waves football team]]. ====1940 NFL All-Star Game (1939 season)==== On January 14, 1940, the 1939 NFL champion [[Green Bay Packers]] met an All-Star team consisting of players from the nine other NFL clubs in the second NFL All-Star game in history. The Packers won 16–7.[http://www.mmbolding.com/BSR/The_January_1940_Pro_Bowl.htm January 1940 NFL Pro Bowl game] ====1940 NFL All-Star Game (1940 season)==== Extra seating was added to accommodate 21,000 fans for the Pro Bowl for the 1940 NFL season. The crowd set a record as the largest to view a Los Angeles pro game.[http://www.mmbolding.com/BSR/The_December_1940_Pro_Bowl.htm December 1940 NFL Pro Bowl game] The event was held on December 29, 1940. The game pitted the 1940 NFL Champion [[Chicago Bears]] against an All-Star team from the other NFL clubs in the third NFL All-Star game. The Bears won 28–14. ===Baseball venue=== The [[Hollywood Stars]] of the [[Pacific Coast League]] played here early in the in 1939 season, while awaiting completion of [[Gilmore Field]]'s construction. The diamond was situated in the southwest "corner" of the stadium, with right field so close that baseballs hit over the fence in that area were ground-rule doubles. ===Midget car venue=== While the first modern day [[midget car racing]] program took place at [[Charles C. Hughes Stadium|Hughes Stadium]] in Sacramento, California in June 1933http://theoldmotor.com/?p=129197, and Loyola Stadium became the starting point in Southern California in August 1933, Gilmore Stadium is often billed as the first track purposely built for the new style of racing. The track hosted midget car racing from the track's debut in May 1934 to 1950.[http://mlsandy.home.tsixroads.com/Corinth_MLSANDY/rt118.html THE GILMORE OIL COMPANY], Reprinted from ''Old Car Illustrated'', Retrieved June 22, 2007 The 1939 [[Turkey Night Grand Prix]] was held at the track.{{cite web|title=Mel Hansen Biography|url=http://www.worthyofhonor.com/Inductees/Mel_Hansen.htm|website=National Midget Auto Racing Hall of Fame|publisher=www.worthyofhonor.com|accessdate=17 October 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927033042/http://www.worthyofhonor.com/Inductees/Mel_Hansen.htm|archivedate=September 27, 2007}} [[Rodger Ward]] drove [[Vic Edelbrock]]'s [[midget car racing|midget car]] in a famous August 10, 1950 event at Gilmore Stadium. Ward shocked the racing world by breaking [[Offenhauser]] engine's winning streak by sweeping the events at Gilmore Stadium that night.{{cite web|title=Vic Edelbrock|url=http://www.worthyofhonor.com/Inductees/Edelbrock_Vic.htm|website=National Midget Auto Racing Hall of Fame|publisher=www.worthyofhonor.com|accessdate=17 October 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927032858/http://www.worthyofhonor.com/Inductees/Edelbrock_Vic.htm|archivedate=September 27, 2007}} Notable drivers that raced at the track include [[Bill Betteridge]], [[Fred Friday]], [[Walt Faulkner]], [[Perry Grimm]], [[Sam Hanks]], [[Curly Mills]], [[Danny Oakes]], [[Roy Russing]], [[Bob Swanson (driver)|Bob Swanson]], [[Bill Vukovich]], [[Rodger Ward]], and [[Karl Young (racing driver)|Karl Young]]. Drivers that were killed at the track include Ed Haddad, [[Swede Lindskog]], Speedy Lockwood, Frankie Lyons, and Chet Mortemore. In the sixteen years of the stadium's existence, over 5 million fans attended races at the track. The stadium drew crowds over 18,000 people each race. Attendance dropped to below 9,000 at normal weekly races by the late 1940s. The attendance drop and increased demand for property in West Hollywood led to the track's sale in 1950. It was torn down in 1951. Some of its grandstand was installed at [[Saugus Speedway]].{{cite book |last=Wilkings |first=Marshall |author2=Lyn Pherigo |title=A Tip of the Hat to Saugus Speedway Champions |year=1982 |url=http://www.scvhistory.com/scvhistory/speedwaychronology.htm | publisher= [[Santa Clarita Valley Historical Society]] |accessdate=2007-12-10 |isbn= }} ===Other uses=== [[File:ThreeLittlePigskins-GilmoreStadium.JPG|thumb|left|360px|Stadium scoreboard and [[Hollywood Hills]] in ''Three Little Pigskins''.]] It also hosted donkey baseball, dog shows, [[rodeo]]s, and at least one [[cricket]] match. [[Esther Williams]] performed in a diving and water ballet performance. A temporary above ground pool was constructed for the event. Several professional boxing title matches where held in the stadium.[http://www.farmersmarketla.com/history/part2.html Farmer's Market (part 2)], Retrieved June 22, 2007 U.S. President [[Harry S. Truman]] delivered his "stiff upper lip" speech in the stadium. Gilmore Stadium was featured in a 1934 [[Three Stooges]] short featuring a football game, and fittingly titled ''[[Three Little Pigskins]]''.{{Cite journal|last=Pauley|first=Jim|year=2003|title=Three Stooges Locations Then and Now: THREE LITTLE PIGSKINS Gilmore Stadium|url=|journal=The Three Stooges Journal|volume=108|pages=6–7|via=}} The scoreboard, with the name of the stadium, appears prominently in several shots, as does a billboard advertising Gilmore products. A sign for the nearby Fairfax Theater, across Beverly Boulevard at the north (open) end of the stadium, is also visible in the background a couple of times. On May 19, 1947, Gilmore Stadium was packed with people waiting to hear a speech by [[Progressive Party (United States, 1948)|Progressive Party]] candidate for President [[Henry A. Wallace]]. Wallace served as vice president under FDR and was also the [[Secretary of Agriculture]] (his specialty) and [[Secretary of Commerce]]. Also speaking at the event was actress [[Katharine Hepburn]], whose speech stole the show. [[File:Truman reelecton rally losangeles.jpg|thumb|Truman re-election rally at Gilmore Stadium, Los Angeles, 1948.Left to right: [[Ronald Reagan]], [[Lauren Bacall]], ?, [[Harry S. Truman]], ?, ?, ?, [[Ned R. Healy]], ?, [[Ellis E. Patterson]], [[Helen Gahagan Douglas]]]] ==References== {{reflist|33em}} {{coord|34|04|28|N|118|21|36|W|type:landmark|display=title}} ==External links== * [http://lainsidertours.lainsidertours.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/The_Farmers_Market_aerial-1930s-1024x651.jpg Colorized postcard of Gilmore Stadium, Gilmore Field, Pan Pacific Auditorium and Farmers Market] * [http://www.digitalballparks.com/PCL/Gilmore.html A collection of pictures of Gilmore Stadiums various usages] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Pro Bowl|NFL All-Star Game]] | years = 1939 and 1940 | before = [[Wrigley Field (Los Angeles)|Wrigley Field]] | after = [[Polo Grounds]] }} {{end}} {{AFL II}} {{Loyola Lions football navbox}} {{Pepperdine Waves football navbox}} [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in the United States]] [[Category:American football venues in Los Angeles]] [[Category:American Football League (1936) venues]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Cricket in California]] [[Category:Cricket grounds in the United States]] [[Category:Hollywood Stars]] [[Category:Loyola Lions football]] [[Category:National Football League venues in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Pepperdine Waves football]] [[Category:Rodeo venues in the United States]] [[Category:Fairfax, Los Angeles]] [[Category:Demolished buildings and structures in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in California]] [[Category:1934 establishments in California]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1934]] [[Category:1952 disestablishments in California]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 1952]]

{{refimprove|date=February 2017}} This is a general glossary of the terms used in the sport of [[gymnastics]].
{{Compact ToC|short1|refs=|num=yes}}
== A == [[File:Gymnastics-Facility-07888-nevit.jpg|thumb|right|Various gymnastics apparatuses. Apparatuses shown include the horizontal (high) bar, the uneven bars, and still rings.]] ;AA: Abbreviation for '''all-around.''' ;AB: A scoring abbreviation for uneven bars, from the name [[Uneven bars|asymmetric bars]]. ;A-score: Under the current ''Code of Points,'' this score tallies the gymnast' counted skills, combinations and EGR. In theory, the A-score can be open-ended, depending on the skills the gymnast presents. ;[[Acrobatic gymnastics]]: A discipline of gymnastics where partners work together to combine the tumbling and power of the floor exercise in artistic gymnastics with the flexibility and artistry of dance. Acrobatic gymnastics routines are performed on the floor apparatus. ;All-around: A competition in which the athletes compete as individuals on all four (women) or six (men) events, also known '''as all-around final'''. ;Apparatus: Specific equipment used in gymnastics. ;[[Artistic gymnastics]]: A discipline of gymnastics in which competitors perform upon apparatuses. ;[[Arabesque (ballet position)|Arabesque]]: Standing on one leg with the other leg raised about 45 degrees ;[[Aerial cartwheel|Aerial]] :A type of cartwheel where a gymnast's hands do not touch the ground. ;[[Aerial twist]]: an acrobatic flip that incorporates a 180° rotation during the peak of the flip's height.
== B == [[File:Beam and feet (close shot).jpg|thumb|right|The balance beam]] ;B-score: Under the current ''Code of Points'', this score rates the gymnast's execution, form, artistry and technique. The judges take their deductions from the 10.0 base score. ;Back-to-back tumbling: A series of skills in which the gymnast executes a tumbling pass from one corner of the mat to the other, rebounds, and performs another tumbling pass in the other direction without stopping. Notably performed by [[Oksana Omelianchik]] (URS), [[Daniela Silivaş]] (ROU) and [[Dominique Dawes]] (USA). ;Balance: One of the three routines in acrobatic gymnastics, highlighted by static hold positions that demonstrate strength, agility and flexibility. ;[[Balance beam]]: A gymnastics apparatus used by women in artistic gymnastics. It is a {{convert|4|in|mm|adj=mid|-wide}} platform upon which gymnasts perform tumbling and dance skills. ;[[Ball (rhythmic gymnastics)|Ball]]: A gymnastics apparatus used in rhythmic gymnastics. The ball rests in the gymnast's hands, is balanced on the body, and is thrown into the air and caught. ;Base: In acrobatic gymnastics, the role in pair and group competition that requires strength and balance. The base is usually an older, larger athlete. ;Bib: The number worn on the gymnast's back, and used in the scoring and roster sheets, to identify them to the judges. ;BB: The scoring abbreviation for [[balance beam]].
== C == ;Chestroll:This skill to bend the back. It is also called a chin stand. ;[[Cartwheel (gymnastics)|Cartwheel]]: The maneuver where one moves sideways, from hands to feet, in a straight line (in the motion that the wheel of a cart would follow), while keeping the back, arms, and legs straight, and the feet pointed. ;Chalk: Carbonate of magnesia, used by gymnasts on their hands, feet and apparatus to make the surface of the equipment less slippery, or to mark lines on the mats. ;Circle: A full circle with the legs together and both hands supporting the gymnast. One of the three basic swings on the [[Pommel Horse]]. ;[[Clubs (rhythmic gymnastics)|Clubs]]: A gymnastics apparatus used in rhythmic gymnastics. ;[[Code of Points (artistic gymnastics)|Code of Points]]: The document that regulates scoring of each discipline. ;Combined: Presented only during acrobatic gymnastics finals, the Combined routine features the elements of both the Balance and the Dynamic (Tempo) routines. ;Competition: Performance in front of a judge which the judge will then score and give points.
== D == ;Dismount: The act of getting off an apparatus and the skill used to do it. ;Dynamic: One of the three routines in acrobatic gymnastics, combining choreography with tumbling sequences and flight elements like throws. ;[[Dive roll|Dive Roll]]: Transitioning from handstand into forward roll.
== E == ;EGR: Abbreviation for '''element group requirements'''. ;Element group requirements: Under the current '''Code of Points,''' the specific required skills, or skill families, that the gymnast must show at some point in his or her routine on each event. For instance, on uneven bars, one of the EGRs is a release move. Currently, there are five EGR skills required on every event. ;Elite: The highest competitive level in gymnastics, or a gymnast who competes at the highest level. The term is used in the USA, Australia and other nations, but is not universal. ;Elementary Gymnastics:Is the type of gymnastics that older gymnasts in training use. It helps them to understand the elements and way of gymnastics. ;[[Elbow stand]]:An inverted pose in which the body is supported on only forearms.
== F == [[File:Jade Barbosa, floor routine, 2007.jpg|thumb|[[Jade Barbosa]] performing her floor routine during a gymnastics competition. The white lines indicate the bounds of the floor.]] ;[[Fédération Internationale de Gymnastique]]: the international sports governing body for gymnastics. Its name is commonly abbreviated as "FIG". ;Flight series: On [[balance beam]], a series of acrobatic skills performed in combination from one end of the beam to the other. ;[[Flip (acrobatic)|Flip]]: A sequence of body movements in which a person leaps into the air and then rotates one or more times while airborne ;[[Floor (gymnastics)|Floor]]: A gymnastics apparatus used by men and women in artistic gymnastics. The event performed upon this apparatus is known as Floor Exercise. ;[[Floor (gymnastics)|Floor exercise]]: The event performed on the floor apparatus. Men and women perform choreographed routines that include tumbling and acrobatic skills. ;[[Freestyle gymnastics]]: A fusion of traditional gymnastic and acrobatic tricks, with kicks and leaps inspired by [[martial arts]], [[parkour]] and [[free running]]. It captures the power and explosive nature of freestyle activities in sport and brings them indoors, performed on a range of purpose built equipment with associated training techniques.<ref>{{cite web|title=British Gymnastics – Free G|url=http://www.british-gymnastics.org/freeg/|publisher=British Gymnastics}}</ref> ;[[Front handspring]] :A gymnastics move in which the gymnast takes a running start, then places their hands as if a handstand. They kick one leg over, push off the ground, and come back up. ;[[Front tuck]]: The act of running, jumping off of 2 feet, turning in mid-air, and landing on the ground on two feet. ;[[Floor exercise|FX]]: The scoring abbreviation for floor exercise.
== G == ;[[Gainer]]: A gymnastics skill in which a gymnast performs a backwards flip while moving forward. ;Grip: See ''[[#H|hand guard]]''. ;[[Gymnastics]]: A sport involving performance of exercises requiring physical strength, agility and coordination. It evolved from exercises used by the ancient Greeks, including skills for mounting and dismounting a horse, and circus eating skills ;[[Giant (gymnastics)|Giant]]: When casting into a handstand position and making a full rotation around the bar while the body is kept in a straight line. ;Good leg [[Split (gymnastics)|split]]: A split with the gymnast's stronger leg forward.
== H == ;[[Hand guard]]: A glove or wrist strap worn by gymnasts to protect the skin on their hands when they perform upon apparatuses. ;HB: The scoring abbreviation for horizontal (or high) bar. ;High Bar: See ''horizontal bar''. ;Hit: To perform a routine or skill to the best of one's ability, with no major errors or deductions. ''Example:'' "He hit the dismount.": May also be used as an adjective to describe a routine performed well. ;[[Hoop (rhythmic gymnastics)|Hoop]]: A gymnastics apparatus used in rhythmic gymnastics. It is a hollow hoop with an interior diameter of 80 to 90 cm. ;[[Horizontal bar]]: A gymnastics apparatus used by men in artistic gymnasts. It consists of one 2.4m bar upon which gymnasts perform skills. It is also known as ''high bar''. ;[[Handstand]]: To stand inverted straight up with squeezed vertical body tension, with hands as a base support on floor.
== I == ;[[Indian club]]s: I:illusion
== J == ;Junior: A world-class/elite gymnast who is too young to compete as a senior, usually between the ages of 13 and 15. ;[[Judge (competition)|Judges]]: Trained professionals who judge gymnasts on their skills on each apparatus. ;[[Jumps]]: A sraight, tucked, piked, straddle or spilt jump
== K == ;[[Kip (artistic gymnastics)|Kip]] : A basic skill in [[artistic gymnastics]] on the uneven bars that is used at a way of getting on the bar in a front support position or a handstand from a hanging or standing position. ;[[Kip (trampolining)|Kip]]: A training skill in [[trampolining]].
== L == [[File:Lauren Mitchell, 41st AG World Championship, 2009 (full tone blur).jpg|thumb|right|Lauren Mitchell performing a layout step-out on the balance beam.]] ;Layout: A position in which the gymnast's body is completely stretched, toes pointed and legs straight.: A layout in [[Tumbling (gymnastics)|tumbling]], [[Vault (gymnastics)|vault]], or [[balance beam]] is a [[Salto (gymnastics)|salto]] performed in this position. In some countries, layout saltos are referred to as "straights" (e.g., "he performed a double straight"). ;[[Leotard]]: A piece of clothing that comes in a variety of colors,shapes and sizes, and is used for gymnastics workouts and competitions.
== M == ;Manna: A strength move pressing with the hands where the legs and hips are raised until the hips are above the shoulders and the legs are parallel to the floor.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rX4zPm95dAY YouTube] demonstration video, uploaded 2008-04-16.</ref> ;[[Master of Sports of the USSR|Master of Sport]]: The term used to refer to a gymnast competing at the highest level of the sport in the USSR. Still used in Russia and other former Soviet republics. ;[[Mat (gymnastics)|Mat]]: Safety equipment used in gymnastics to break falls. ;Meet: A commonly used term for a gymnastics competition. ;Middle: In acrobatic gymnastics, the role in group competition that requires a combination of strength, balance, flexibility and power. ;Mount: The act of getting onto an apparatus and the skill used to do it.
== N == ;Neutral deduction: A score deduction which is taken as a penalty for violations of rules not related directly to the gymnasts' performance, for instance, failure to adhere to required standards of competition attire. Neutral deductions may be applied against a team's cumulative score as well as against individual gymnasts. ;Number: See ''[[#B|bib]].'' ;Needle: To put two hands on the floor and one leg on the floor, then kick the other leg into a full split.
== O == ;OOB: Abbreviation for [[out of bounds]]. ;Out of bounds: Situation on [[floor exercise]] or [[Vault (gymnastics)]] when a gymnast crosses the line indicating the border of the mat, resulting in a score deduction. ;Onodi: A backhandspring with a half turn mid air, in which a gymnast finishes with a front walkover.
== P == ;[[Parallel bars (gymnastics)|Parallel bars]]: A gymnastics apparatus used by men in artistic gymnastics. It consists of two 3.5m bars. ;PB: The scoring abbreviation for the parallel bars. ;PH: The scoring abbreviation for the pommel horse. ;Pike: a position where the body is bent only in the hips. ;[[Pommel horse]]: A gymnastics apparatus used by men in artistic gymnastics. It consists of a rectangular body and two pommels. ;Posture: Movement of the body ;pullover: a move on bars in which the gymnast starts off the bar, then uses her are strength to pull herself up and over the bar. ;Press hand stand: the gymnasts starts on the floor in a straddle then pushes all her body weight onto her hands and presses into a handstand.
== R == [[File:PaisievaRibbon.jpg|thumb|right|[[Elizabeth Paisieva]], a rhythmic gymnast, performing with a ribbon]] ;Release move or release: Skill on the uneven bars, parallel bars or high bar in which the gymnast lets go of the apparatus, performs a skill in the air, and regrasps the bar. ;[[Ribbon (rhythmic gymnastics)|Ribbon]]: A gymnastics apparatus used in rhythmic gymnastics. The ribbon is a long piece of material attached to a stick. ;Rings: See ''[[#S|still rings]]''. ;[[Roundoff]] :A type of cartwheel where the gymnast pushes off the ground and lands on two feet. ;[[Roll (gymnastics)|Roll]]: A roll is a rotation over an axis in the body over a surface. ;[[Rope (rhythmic gymnastics)|Rope]]: A gymnastics apparatus used in rhythmic gymnastics. It is made of a material that retains the qualities of lightness and suppleness. It is knotted at the end. ;[[Rhythmic gymnastics]]: A discipline of gymnastics in which competitors manipulate apparatuses. The sport combines elements of ballet, gymnastics, theatrical dance, and apparatus manipulation. Athletes are scored on their leaps, balances, pivots, flexibility, apparatus handling, and artistic effect.
== S == ;[[Salto (gymnastics)|Salto]]: A somersault. ;Score protest: A written complaint, submitted by the gymnast or their coaches or federation, to request reconsideration and possible revision of scores felt to be incorrect or unfair. Under FIG rules, protests must be filed immediately after the original score is reported, and before the end of the competition. ;Senior: A world-class/elite gymnast who is at least 16, or will be turning 16, within the calendar year. ;[[Somersault]]: A gymnastics maneuver in which a person rotates around the somersault axis, moving the feet over the head. ;Specialist: A gymnast who is especially strong on one or two events. A specialist often competes only on his or her specific events. ;[[Springboard]]: Gymnastics equipment required on vault, and used as an optional aid for mounts on parallel bars, balance beam and uneven bars. ;SR: The scoring abbreviation for the still rings. ;Start value: Under the pre-2006 ''Code of Points,'' the maximum score a gymnast could receive for a routine, after taking into consideration all bonus skills, combinations and fulfillment of required elements. The score was determined by subtracting deductions from the start value. ;Stick: To land an acrobatic skill, jump, or dismount perfectly, without any steps, stumbles or errors. ;[[Rings (gymnastics)|Still rings]]: A gymnastics apparatus used by men in artistic gymnastics. It consists of two swinging hollow rings suspended by a frame. ;Straddle: A sitting position with the legs wide. It can also be performed at height. ;Stuck landing: A perfect landing, without any steps, stumbles or errors. ;SV: Abbreviation for '''start value'''. ;[[Splits]]: You go to the ground with one leg in front of you and one behind you
== T == ;Team final, or TF: A team of 6 gymnasts (or 5 gymnasts at the [[2012 London Olympics]]), representing a country, for the team competition. ;[[Pointe shoe|Toe shoes]]: Shoes commonly worn by rhythmic gymnasts to perform turns. ;Top: In acrobatic gymnastics, the role in pair and group competition that emphasizes flexibility and agility. The top is usually a younger, smaller athlete. ;[[Tsukahara (vault)|Tsukahara]]: A vault and family of vaults. The vault consists of a half turn off the springboard onto the vault table, then a push backwards, usually into a back salto or layout. Any vault that has a handspring with ¼ – ½ turn onto the vault table into a salto backwards is classified as a Tsukahara vault. It is named after [[Mitsuo Tsukahara]]. ;Tumbling: The acrobatic skills performed on [[floor exercise]] and [[balance beam]], such as back handsprings and saltos. Also, a [[Tumbling (gymnastics)|specific discipline]] of gymnastics, performed on a 25-meter-long dynamic track, in which participants perform tumbling skills. ;Tumbling run, or tumbling pass: A series of acrobatic skills performed on floor from one corner of the mat to the other, typically beginning with a run and hurtle and ending with a major salto. ;Tuck: A jump with knees to chest. ;Twist: A [[#L|layout]] with axial body rotation in addition to the fundamental rotation about the waist <!-- ==U== -->
== V == [[File:DHypolito-Vault.jpg|thumb|right|Diego Hypólito rotates in the air after the vaulting table.]] ;[[Vault (gymnastics)|Vault]]: A gymnastics apparatus used by both men and women in artistic gymnastics, or the skills performed upon it, which consists of a . : To perform a vaulting skill. ;VT: The scoring abbreviation for "vault".
== W == ;[[Warming up|Warm-up]]: The period and techniques that aim to warm up the gymnasts muscles in order for them not to injure themselves while stretching or training. <!-- == X == ;X-jump -->
== Y == ;[[Yurchenko loop]]: A balance beam skill in which the gymnasts stands sideways on the beam, dives backwards into a back handspring (the "loop"), grasps the beam, performs a back hip circle and ends up in a front support position, resting on the hands. It is named after [[Natalia Yurchenko]]. ;[[Yurchenko (vault)|Yurchenko vault]]: A vault and a family of vaults. It consists of a round-off onto the springboard and a back handspring onto the horse or vaulting table, followed by a salto. Any vault with a roundoff-back handspring entry is classified as a "Yurchenko-style" vault. It is named after [[Natalia Yurchenko]]. <!-- == Z == zero handed sausage roll(the food not the dance move) -->
== References == <references />

{{Infobox organization |name = International Orienteering Federation |bgcolor = |fgcolor = |image = IOF logo.png |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = |map = International Orienteering Federation members.png |msize = 300px |malt = |mcaption = Map of the members of the IOF according to their region. |abbreviation = IOF |motto = |formation = {{Start date and years ago|1961|05|21}} |extinction = |type = [[List of international sport federations|Federation of national sports associations]] |status = |purpose = |headquarters = Drottninggatan 47 3-1/2 tr
[[Karlstad]]
[[Sweden]] |location = |coords = |region_served = Worldwide |membership = 73 national federations |language = |leader_title = President |leader_name = [[Leho Haldna]] |leader_title2= Secretary General |leader_name2 = Tom Hollowell |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = [[International Olympic Committee]] |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = {{URL|http://www.orienteering.org/}} |remarks = }} The '''International Orienteering Federation''' ('''IOF''') is the international governing body of the sport of [[orienteering]]. The IOF head office is located in [[Karlstad Municipality|Karlstad, Sweden]].{{cite web |url=http://orienteering.org/about-the-iof/secretariat/ |title=Secretariat |accessdate=2011-08-02 |publisher=International Orienteering Federation |date= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110626093920/http://orienteering.org/about-the-iof/secretariat/ |archivedate=2011-06-26 |df= }} The IOF governs four orienteering disciplines: [[foot orienteering]], [[mountain bike orienteering]], [[ski orienteering]], and [[trail orienteering]].{{cite web |url=http://orienteering.org/about-the-iof/the-iof/ |title= About the IOF|accessdate=2011-08-02 |publisher=International Orienteering Federation |date= }} ==History== The IOF was founded on 21 May 1961 at a Congress held in Copenhagen, [[Denmark]] by the orienteering national federations of [[Bulgarian Orienteering Federation|Bulgaria]], Czechoslovakia, [[Dansk Orienterings-Forbund (DOF)|Denmark]], the Federal Republic of Germany, the German Democratic Republic, [[Finnish Orienteering Federation|Finland]], [[Magyar Tájékozódási Futó Szövetség|Hungary]], [[Norges Orienteringsforbund|Norway]], [[Svenska Orienteringsförbundet|Sweden]] and [[Swiss Orienteering|Switzerland]].{{cite web|url=http://orienteering.org/about-the-iof/history/|title=History |publisher=International Orienteering Federation|accessdate=2011-08-02}} By 1969, the IOF represented 16 countries, including its first two non-European member federations representing [[Nihon Orienteering Kyokai|Japan]] and [[Canadian Orienteering Federation|Canada]],{{cite web |url=http://www.momentech.com.au/droc/HistoryOrienteering.asp |title=Orienteering History |last=Dandenong Ranges Orienteering Club |publisher=Momentech Software Services |accessdate=2006-02-19 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060108211727/http://www.momentech.com.au/droc/HistoryOrienteering.asp |archivedate=2006-01-08 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and in 1977 the IOF was recognised by the [[International Olympic Committee]]. ==Membership== As of January 2016, the membership of the IOF comprises 80 national orienteering federations, of which 56 are members, 24 are provisional members,{{cite web|url=http://orienteering.org/about-the-iof/national-federations/|title=National Federations|publisher=International Orienteering Federation|accessdate=2011-08-02}} divided into six geographical regions.{{cite web|url=http://orienteering.org/about-the-iof/regions/|title=Regions|publisher=International Orienteering Federation|accessdate=2011-08-02}} === Africa === '''6 Members, 1 Provisional Member''' {| |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|Cameroon}} [[Cameroon Orienteering Sport Association|Cameroon]] * {{flagicon|Egypt}} ''[[The Egyptian Orienteering Federation|Egypt]]'' * {{flagicon|Kenya}} [[Bushtrekkers Orienteering Club Kenya|Kenya]] * {{flagicon|Mozambique}} [[Associacao de Orientacao da Cidade de Maputo (AOCM)|Mozambique]] |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|Somalia}} [[Somali Orienteering Federation|Somalia]] * {{flagicon|South Africa}} [[The South African Orienteering Federation|South Africa]] * {{flagicon|Uganda}} [[Uganda Orienteering Federation|Uganda]] |} === Asia === '''14 Members, 2 Provisional Members''' {| |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|China}} [[Orienteering Association of China|China]] * {{flagicon|Chinese Taipei}} [[Chinese Taipei Orienteering Association|Chinese Taipei]] * {{flagicon|Hong Kong}} [[Orienteering Association of Hong Kong|Hong Kong]] * {{flagicon|India}} [[Orienteering Federation of India|India]] |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|Indonesia}} [[Federation Orienteering National of Indonesia (FONI)|Indonesia]] * {{flagicon|Iran}} ''[[Iran Federation of Sport Associations|Iran]]'' * {{flagicon|Japan}} [[Japanese Orienteering Federation|Japan]] * {{flagicon|Kazakhstan}} [[Sport Orienteering Federation of the Republic of Kazakhstan|Kazakhstan]] |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|Kyrgyzstan}} [[Kyrgyzstan Orienteering Federation|Kyrgyzstan]] * {{flagicon|Malaysia}} [[Malaysian Orienteering Association (MOA)|Malaysia]] * {{flagicon|Mongolia}} [[Mongolian Orienteering Federation|Mongolia]] * {{flagicon|Nepal}} ''[[Nepal Orienteering Federation|Nepal]]'' |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|North Korea}} [[Amateur Orienteering Association of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea|North Korea]] * {{flagicon|Pakistan}} [[Pakistan Orienteering Association|Pakistan]] * {{flagicon|South Korea}} [[Korea Orienteering Federation|South Korea]] * {{flagicon|Thailand}} [[Thailand's Orienteering Association|Thailand]] |} === Europe === '''40 Members''' {| |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|Austria}} [[Österreichischer Fachverband für Orientierungslauf|Austria]] * {{flagicon|Azerbaijan}} [[Azerbaijan Orienteering Federation|Azerbaijan]] * {{flagicon|Belgium}} [[Belgian Orienteering Federation ABSO-BVOS|Belgium]] * {{flagicon|Belarus}} [[Belarus Orienteering Federation|Belarus]] * {{flagicon|Bulgaria}} [[Bulgarian Orienteering Federation|Bulgaria]] * {{flagicon|Croatia}} [[Croatian Orienteering Federation|Croatia]] * {{flagicon|Cyprus}} [[KOMOAA|Cyprus]] * {{flagicon|Czech Republic}} [[Cesky svaz orientacniho behu (CSOB)|Czech Republic]] |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|Denmark}} [[Dansk Orienterings-Forbund (DOF)|Denmark]] * {{flagicon|Estonia}} [[Eesti Orienteerumisliit|Estonia]] * {{flagicon|Finland}} [[Finnish Orienteering Federation|Finland]] * {{flagicon|France}} [[Fédération Française de Course d'Orientation (FFCO)|France]] * {{flagicon|Georgia}} [[Georgian Orienteering Federation (GeOF)|Georgia]] * {{flagicon|Germany}} [[Deutscher Turner Bund, Abteilung Sport Orientierungslauf|Germany]] * {{flagicon|Great Britain}} [[British Orienteering Federation (BOF)|Great Britain]] * {{flagicon|Greece}} [[Hellenic Orienteering Club|Greece]] |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|Hungary}} [[Magyar Tájékozódási Futó Szövetség|Hungary]] * {{flagicon|Ireland}} [[Irish Orienteering Association|Ireland]] * {{flagicon|Israel}} [[Israel Sport Orienteering Association|Israel]] * {{flagicon|Italy}} [[Federazione Italiana Sport Orientamento (FISO)|Italy]] * {{flagicon|Latvia}} [[Latvijas Orientesanas Federacija (LOF)|Latvia]][http://www.lof.lv/ lof.lv] * {{flagicon|Liechtenstein}} [[Orientierungslaufclub des Fürstentums Liechtenstein (OL FL)|Liechtenstein]] * {{flagicon|Lithuania}} [[Lithuanian Orienteering Federation (LOSF)|Lithuania]] * {{flagicon|Macedonia}} [[Macedonian Orienteering Sport|Macedonia]] |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|Moldova}} [[Moldavian Orienteering Federation|Moldova]] * {{flagicon|Montenegro}} [[Mountaineering Association of Montenegro|Montenegro]] * {{flagicon|Netherlands}} [[Nederlandse Orienteringsloop Bond|Netherlands]] * {{flagicon|Norway}} [[Norges Orienteringsforbund|Norway]] * {{flagicon|Poland}} [[Polski Związek Orientacji Sportowej|Poland]] * {{flagicon|Portugal}} [[Federacão Portuguesa de Orientacão (FPO)|Portugal]] * {{flagicon|Romania}} [[Romanian Orienteering Federation|Romania]] * {{flagicon|Russia}} [[Russian Orienteering Federation|Russia]] |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|Serbia}} [[Serbian Orienteering Federation|Serbia]] * {{flagicon|Slovakia}} [[Slovensky zvaz OB|Slovakia]] * {{flagicon|Slovenia}} [[Orientacijska Zveza Slovenije|Slovenia]] * {{flagicon|Spain}} [[Federatión Española de Orientación (FEDO)|Spain]] * {{flagicon|Sweden}} [[Svenska Orienteringsförbundet|Sweden]] * {{flagicon|Switzerland}} [[Swiss Orienteering|Switzerland]] * {{flagicon|Turkey}} [[Turkish Orienteering Federation|Turkey]] * {{flagicon|Ukraine}} [[Ukrainian Orienteering Federation|Ukraine]] |} === North America === '''5 Members''' {| |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|Barbados}} [[Barbados Orienteering Federation|Barbados]] * {{flagicon|Canada}} [[Canadian Orienteering Federation|Canada]] * {{flagicon|Jamaica}} [[Jamaica Orienteering Federation|Jamaica]] |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|Puerto Rico}} [[Puerto Rico Sports for All|Puerto Rico]] * {{flagicon|United States}} [[Orienteering USA|United States]] |} === Oceania === '''2 Members''' {| |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|Australia}} [[Orienteering Australia|Australia]] |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|New Zealand}} [[New Zealand Orienteering Federation|New Zealand]] |} === South America === '''9 Members''' {| |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|Argentina}} [[Federacion del Deporte de Orientacion de la Republica Argentina|Argentina]] * {{flagicon|Brazil}} [[Confederacao Brasileira de Orientacao|Brazil]] * {{flagicon|Chile}} [[The Chilean Orienteering Federation|Chile]] |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|Colombia}} [[Federación Colombiana de Orientación|Colombia]] * {{flagicon|Cuba}} [[Cuban Orienteering Federation|Cuba]] * {{flagicon|Ecuador}} [[The Orienteering Federation of Ecuador|Ecuador]] |width=200 valign=top| * {{flagicon|Panama}} [[Panama Orienteering Club|Panama]] * {{flagicon|Uruguay}} [[Uruguayan Orienteering Association|Uruguay]] * {{flagicon|Venezuela}} [[Club de Senderismo y Orientacion Deportiva|Venezuela]] |} ==Governance structure== The IOF is governed by an elected Council consisting of a President, a Senior Vice President, two Vice Presidents, and seven other Council members.{{cite web|url=http://orienteering.org/about-the-iof/council/|title=Council|publisher=International Orienteering Federation|accessdate=2011-08-02}} Day-to-day operations of the IOF are the responsibility of the IOF Secretary General. Several standing commissions of the IOF are responsible for the development of the [[sport]] worldwide. These commissions include: [[foot orienteering|Foot Orienteering]], [[Mountain bike orienteering|MTB Orienteering]], [[Ski-orienteering|Ski Orienteering]], [[Trail orienteering|Trail Orienteering]], Environment, IT, [[Orienteering map|Map]], Medical, and Rules. ===Presidents{{cite web|url=http://orienteering.org/about-the-iof/history/past-and-present-councils/|title=Past and present Councils|publisher=IOF|accessdate=2013-12-23}}{{cite web|url=http://orienteering.org/leho-haldna-from-estonia-is-the-new-iof-president/|title=Leho Haldna from Estonia is the new IOF President|publisher=IOF|accessdate=2017-08-04}}=== * [[Erik Tobé]] (1961—1975) * [[Lasse Heideman]] (1975—1982) * [[Bengt Saltin]] (1982—1988) * [[Heinz Tschudin]] (1988—1994) * [[Sue Harvey]] (1994—2004) * [[Åke Jacobson]] (2004—2012) * [[Brian Porteous]] (2012—2016) * [[Leho Haldna]] (2016—) ==Affiliations== Since 1977, the IOF has been recognised by the [[International Olympic Committee]]. The IOF is also a member of the following organisations: *[[Association of IOC Recognised International Sports Federations]] (ARISF) *[[International World Games Association]] (IWGA) *[[World Masters Games#International Masters Games Association|International Masters Games Association]] (IMGA) *[[SportAccord]] ==Publications== The IOF publishes a wide variety of journals and reference works related to the sport. These include ''Orienteering World'', an annual magazine, ''The Scientific Journal of Orienteering'', the ''OZine'',{{cite web|url=http://orienteering.org/resources/publications/|title=Publications|publisher=International Orienteering Federation|accessdate=2011-08-02}} and official editions of the rules of IOF sanctioned [[orienteering]]{{cite web|url=http://orienteering.org/resources/rules/|title=Rules|publisher=International Orienteering Federation|accessdate=2011-08-02}} and specifications for [[orienteering map]]s.{{cite web|url=http://orienteering.org/resources/mapping/|title=Mapping|publisher=International Orienteering Federation|accessdate=2011-08-02}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{International Orienteering Federation Members}} {{Orienteering|type=collapsed}} {{International Sports Federations}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:International Orienteering Federation]] [[Category:International sports organizations]] [[Category:IOC-recognised international federations]] [[Category:Orienteering]] [[Category:Orienteering in Sweden]] [[Category:Outdoor recreation organizations]] [[Category:Sport in Karlstad]] [[Category:Sports governing bodies in Sweden]] [[Category:Sports organisations established in 1961]] [[Category:1961 establishments in Denmark]]

{{Infobox venue | name = Menominee Nation Arena | nickname = | fullname = | former names = Oshkosh Arena (pre-opening) | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = [[File:MenomineeNationArena.png|125px]]
[[File:MenomineeNationArena31Dec2017.jpg|300px]] | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = December 2017 | pushpin_map = USA Wisconsin#USA | pushpin_mapsize = 200 | pushpin_relief = yes | pushpin_map_caption = Location in Wisconsin / United States | pushpin_label_position = right | address = | location = South Main Street
[[Oshkosh, Wisconsin|Oshkosh]], [[Wisconsin]], United States | coordinates = {{coord|44|00|27|N|88|32|15|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | type = Multi-purpose arena | genre = Music, concerts, and sporting events | broke_ground = March 29, 2017 | built = 2017 | opened = {{Start date|2017|12|01|mdy}} | owner = Fox Valley Pro Basketball | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = Yes | cost = [[United States dollar|$]]15 million{{cite web|url=http://fox11online.com/news/local/fox-cities/oshkosh-common-council-approves-bucks-d-league-arena-plans |title=Oshkosh Common Council approves Bucks D-League arena plans | WLUK |publisher=Fox11online.com |date=2017-01-24 |accessdate=2017-07-13}}
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|15000000|2016}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = | builder = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = Bayland Buildings | main_contractors = | seating_type = | capacity = 3,500 | suites = | record_attendance = | tenants = [[Wisconsin Herd]] ([[NBA G League]]) (2017–present) | website = {{URL|menomineenationarena.com}} | publictransit = }} The '''Menominee Nation Arena''' is a {{convert|64300|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} [[indoor arena]] located in [[Oshkosh, Wisconsin|Oshkosh]], in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Wisconsin]]. The facility is primarily used for [[basketball]]. It serves as the home of the [[Wisconsin Herd]] of the [[NBA G League]], which is affiliated with the [[Milwaukee Bucks]] of the [[National Basketball Association]].{{cite web|url=http://dleague.nba.com/news/milwaukee-bucks-purchase-nba-development-league-team/ |title=Milwaukee Bucks Purchase NBA Development League Team - NBA G League |publisher=Dleague.nba.com |date= |accessdate=2017-07-13}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/bucks/release/milwaukee-bucks-purchase-nba-development-league-team-begin-play-oshkosh-2017-18-season |title=Milwaukee Bucks Purchase NBA Development League Team to Begin Play in Oshkosh for the 2017-18 Season | Milwaukee Bucks |publisher=Nba.com |date=2014-05-15 |accessdate=2017-07-13}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/bucks/dleague/ |title=Wisconsin Herd |publisher=Nba.com |date= |accessdate=2017-07-13}} The first event to be held at the arena, a Wisconsin Herd game was on December 1, 2017.{{cite web|last1=Blair|first1=Nolan|title=Wisconsin Herd play first game in Menominee Nation Arena|url=http://www.wbay.com/content/news/Wisconsin-Herd--461415413.html|accessdate=3 December 2017|language=en}} ==Location and design== The arena is located along the east side of South Main Street, on the former site of the Buckstaff Furniture Company. With a seating capacity of 3,500 spectators, the new arena broke ground on March 29, 2017,{{cite web|url=http://www.wbay.com/content/news/Groundbreaking-today-for-Bucks-D-League-arena-in-Oshkosh-417440083.html|title=Groundbreaking for Bucks D-League arena in Oshkosh|publisher=Wbay.com|date=March 29, 2017|accessdate=August 1, 2017}} with completion slated for late November. [[File:Oshkosh Arena dismantlement of Buckstaff Furniture Building Feb 2017.jpg|thumb|300px|Razing the Buckstaff building in February 2017]] ==History== On January 25, 2017, the Oshkosh City Council unanimously approved the construction of the $15 million facility. The cost of the construction was privately funded, with the arena being part of a larger development plan for a new housing and commercial area called the Sawdust District, located near Pioneer Drive Park along the shores of [[Lake Winnebago]].{{cite web|url=http://arenadigest.com/2017/01/25/oshkosh-approves-d-league-arena-deal/|title=Oshkosh Approves D-League Arena Deal|publisher=ArenaDigest.com|date=January 25, 2017|accessdate=August 1, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://fox11online.com/news/local/fox-cities/plans-submitted-for-oshkosh-basketball-arena|title=Plans submitted for Oshkosh basketball arena|publisher=Fox11Online.com|date=December 26, 2016|accessdate=August 1, 2017}} On June 13, 2017, the Oshkosh City Council announced that the arena was to receive an additional $250,000 in state-supported funding for improvement of the nearby roadways and infrastructures to improve transit to the facility.{{cite web|url=http://www.fdlreporter.com/story/money/2017/06/12/wedc-awards-oshkosh-250-000-grant-roadwork-near-new-arena/390114001/|title=WEDC awards Oshkosh $250,000 grant for roadwork near new arena|publisher=FDLReporter.com|date=June 12, 2017|accessdate=August 1, 2017}} On October 23, 2017, the [[Menominee]] Native American tribe announced that they had purchased the naming rights to the arena, giving it the '''Menominee Nation Arena''' name. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.{{Cite news |url=http://www.jsonline.com/story/news/2017/10/23/menominee-tribe-buys-naming-rights-wisconsin-herd-arena-oshkosh/783400001/ |title=Menominee tribe buys naming rights for Wisconsin Herd arena in Oshkosh |last=Nelson |first=James B. |date=October 23, 2017 |work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] |access-date=October 23, 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Menominee Nation Arena}} * [https://www.menomineenationarena.com/ Menominee Nation Arena] {{D-League Arenas}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Sports venues in Wisconsin]] [[Category:NBA G League arenas]] [[Category:2017 establishments in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Sports in Oshkosh, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Wisconsin Herd]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2017]] {{Wisconsin-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.comment: Cleaning up accepted [[Wikipedia:Articles for creation|Articles for creation]] submission ([[WP:AFCH|AFCH]] 0.9)
revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Merlis Belsher Place | nickname = | image = [[File:Merlis_Belsher_Place.jpg|250px]] | location = [[University of Saskatchewan]],
[[Saskatoon]], [[Saskatchewan]]
{{CAN}} | coordinates = {{Coord|52.126190|-106.626686|type:landmark_region:CA-SK|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 2017 | opened = 2018 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = University of Saskatchewan | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = [[Canadian dollar|C]]$51 million | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Saskatchewan Huskies]] ([[U Sports]])
Saskatoon Contacts (SMHA)
Saskatoon Stars (SMHA) | seating_capacity = [[Ice hockey]]: 2,700 | dimensions = }} '''Merlis Belsher Place''' is an arena located at the [[University of Saskatchewan]] in [[Saskatoon]], [[Saskatchewan]], Canada. It is the current home of the [[University of Saskatchewan Huskies]] men and women's hockey teams, as well as the Saskatoon Contacts and Saskatoon Stars of the Saskatoon Minor Hockey Association.{{cite web |url=https://globalnews.ca/news/4300119/saskatoon-stars-contacts-merlis-belsher-place/ |title=Saskatoon Stars and Contacts moving to Merlis Belsher Place |publisher=Global News |date=June 27, 2018 |website=Global News |access-date=November 22, 2018}} ==History== In 2016, the University of Saskatchewan announced plans to build a new athletics facility to replace the 90 year-old [[Rutherford Arena]]. Originally budgeted to cost $41 million dollars, the University sought to raise the necessary funds through its Home Ice Campaign, which sought donations and fundraising opportunities from alumni, minor hockey associations, and the City of Saskatoon. The arena was named in honour of Merlis Belsher, an alumni of the University's Faculty of Law, following a donation of $12.25 million dollars to the Campaign.{{cite web |url=https://saskatoon.ctvnews.ca/university-of-saskatchewan-announces-plan-for-new-41-million-rink-1.3114160 |title=University of Saskatchewan announces plan for new $41-million rink |publisher=CTV Saskatoon |date=October 13, 2016 |website=CTV Saskatoon |access-date=November 22, 2018}} Construction on the facility officially began on April 28, 2017 with a ground-breaking ceremony.{{cite web |url=https://globalnews.ca/news/3414789/merlis-belsher-place-ground-breaking-at-university-of-saskatchewan/ |title=Merlis Belsher Place groundbreaking ceremony held at University of Saskatchewan |publisher=Global News |date=April 28, 2017 |website=Global News |access-date=November 22, 2018}} The arena was completed in time for the beginning of the 2018-19 Huskies season, with the women's team hosting the first game in the arena's history on October 5, 2018.{{cite web |url=https://www.canadawest.org/sports/wice/2018-19/releases/20181006ely0x7 |title=WHKY: Huskies shutout Pandas, open Merlis Belsher Place in style |date=October 5, 2018 |website=Canada West |access-date=November 22, 2018}} ==Facilities== Merlis Belsher Place was designed to replace several aging facilities at the University of Saskatchewan. As part of an agreement with the City of Saskatoon, Merlis Belsher Place features two NHL-sized ice surfaces which can be utilized year round and will provide an added 1,500 hours of icetime for minor hockey in the City.{{cite web |url=https://news.usask.ca/articles/huskies/2017/city-boosts-support-for-home-ice-campaign.php |title=City boosts support for Home Ice Campaign |access-date=2018-11-22}} The facility also features two NBA-sized [[basketball]] courts which will be used as practice space for the University's basketball teams, as well as team rooms for the University's soccer teams and numerous change rooms that are meant to be used by community groups.{{cite web |url=http://merlisbelsherplace.ca/facility/ |title=About Us |access-date=2018-11-22}} The basketball courts are named in honour of Ron and Jane Graham, who contributed $4 million dollars to ensure their inclusion in the new arena.{{cite web |url=https://alumni.usask.ca/news/2018/merlis-belsher-place-construction-hits-halfway-mark.php |title=Merlis Belsher Place construction hits halfway mark |access-date=2018-11-22}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://merlisbelsherplace.ca/}} {{University of Saskatchewan}} [[Category:University of Saskatchewan|Merlis Belsher Place]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Canada]] [[Category:University sports venues in Canada]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Saskatoon]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2018]] [[Category:University of Saskatchewan|Merlis Belsher Place]] [[Category:University and college buildings in Canada]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Canada]] [[Category:University sports venues in Canada]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Saskatchewan]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Saskatoon]] [[Category:Sports venues in Saskatchewan]] [[Category:Sport in Saskatoon]] [[Category:Saskatchewan Huskies]] [[Category:Sport in Saskatoon]] [[Category:Saskatchewan Huskies]] {{Canada-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Ref improve|date= November 2014}} {{Infobox_Stadium | stadium_name = Molde idrettspark | nickname = | image = [[File:Molde idrettspark IMG 0289.jpg|300px]] | location = [[Molde]], [[Norway]] | coordinates = {{Coord|62.740479|N|7.155275|E|format=dms|display=inline,title|type:landmark_region:NO}} | broke_ground = | opened = 28 August 1955 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Molde Municipality | operator = | surface = Grass
[[All-weather running track]] | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = Molde stadion (–1998) | tenants = [[SK Træff]] (football)
[[IL Molde-Olymp]] (athletics)
[[Molde FK]] (football, 1955–1998) | seating_capacity = 15,000 | record_attendance = 14,615 }} '''Molde idrettspark''', until 1998 known as '''Molde stadion''', is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] located in [[Molde]], [[Norway]]. It serves as the home ground for the [[athletics (sport)|athletics]] team [[IL Molde-Olymp]] and the [[association football|football]] clubs [[SK Træff]] and reserve and development teams of [[Molde FK]]. Prior to the 1998 opening of [[Aker Stadion]] it also served as the home ground for Molde FK's [[Norwegian Premier League]] team. The stadium opened on 28 August 1955 and has a capacity for 15,000 spectators. ==History== The venue opened on 28 August 1955 in a league match between Molde FK and [[Kristiansund FK]], with the home team winning 1–0. Until then Molde FK had been playing their games at Rivalbanen.{{cite web |url=http://www.moldefk.no/1950-1959/article/eo9fuzov2g0s1x7po8ja6s6ic/title/1955 |title=1955 |publisher=[[Molde FK]] |language=Norwegian |accessdate=15 July 2012}} Molde played in the top league, the [[Tippeligaen|Main League]] in 1958, after which the stadium was not used for top-level football again until Molde was promoted to the [[1974 Norwegian First Division]]. That year saw an expansion of the terraces. The seated stand was built by the club in the mid-1980s. However, the costs were too much for the club to bear and was a contributing factor to the club's near bankruptcy in 1991. The record attendance of 14,615 dates from a 1987 match against [[Moss FK]]. The A-team moved to Molde Stadion (now Aker Stadion) in 1998.{{cite web |url=http://www.mfkweb.org/anlegg.php?vis=idrettspark |title=Molde idrettspark |publisher=MFKweb |language=Norwegian |accessdate=15 July 2012}} ==References== {{commons category|Molde idrettspark}} {{reflist}} {{Molde FK}} {{Eliteserien venues}} [[Category:Molde FK]] [[Category:Football venues in Norway]] [[Category:Eliteserien venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Molde]] [[Category:1955 establishments in Norway]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1955]]
