Scotland (2), Italy (2), South Africa (2) {{efn|group=pr|The two South African teams that were dropped from Super Rugby after its 2017 season joined the renamed Pro14 for the 2017–18 season.}} | 8,586 |- | [[Mitre 10 Cup]] | 14 | [[New Zealand Rugby|New Zealand]] | 7,203 |- | [[Rugby Pro D2]] | 16 | [[French Rugby Federation|France]] | 4,222 |- | [[RFU Championship]] | 12 | [[Rugby Football Union|England]] | 2,738 |- | [[Major League Rugby]] | 7 | [[USA Rugby|United States]] | Unknown |- | [[National Rugby Championship|NRC]] | 9 | [[Australian Rugby Union|Australia]] (8), [[Fiji Rugby Union|Fiji]] (1) | 1,450 |- | [[Didi 10]] | 10 | Georgia | Unknown |} {{notelist|group=pr}} ==Variants== {{main article|Rugby sevens}} [[File:Spielszene BK.jpg|thumb|[[Beach rugby]] match|alt=On a sunlit beach two teams of players, one in yellow the other in blue, play a form of rugby; the central yellow player runs forward clutching the ball with one hand, close to his chest.]] The game of rugby union has spawned several variants of the full-contact, 15-a-side code. The two more common differences applied to the variants of the sport lie in either fewer players or reduced player contact. Of the variants, the oldest is [[Rugby sevens]] (7's, or VIIs), a fast-paced variant which originated in [[Melrose, Scotland|Melrose]], Scotland in 1883. In rugby sevens, there are only seven players per side, and each half is normally seven minutes. Major tournaments include the [[Hong Kong Sevens]] and [[Dubai Sevens]], both held in areas not normally associated with the highest levels of the 15-a-side game. A more recent variant of the sport is [[Rugby tens]] (10's or Xs), a Malaysian variant with ten players per side.{{Harvnb|Bath|1997|p=71}} Due to the physical nature of playing rugby, several variants have been created to introduce the sport to children with a reduced level of physical contact.{{cite web|url=https://passport.worldrugby.org/beginners_guide/downloads/Beginners_Guide_2015_EN.pdf |work=[[World Rugby]] |title=A Beginner's Guide to Rugby Union |pages=14–15|accessdate=28 September 2015}} Of these versions, [[Touch rugby]], in which "tackles" are made by simply touching the ball carrier with two hands, is popular as a mixed sex version of the sport played by both children and adults.{{cite web|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/sport/getting-a-kick-out-of-touch/story-e6frep5o-1225699224845 |title=Touch rugby league growing in Brisbane |first=Karl|last=deKroo| work=The Courier-Mail |date=11 April 2009 |accessdate=23 September 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.rfu.com/TheGame/~/link.aspx?_id=A4A528E2CC22410390D89AE5E46D1EF9&_z=z |title=Touch Rugby |work=[[Rugby Football Union|RFU]] |accessdate=24 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110919021954/https://www.rfu.com/TheGame/%7E/link.aspx?_id=A4A528E2CC22410390D89AE5E46D1EF9&_z=z |archivedate=19 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }} [[Tag Rugby]], is a version in which the participants wear a belt with two hook-and-loop fastener tags, the removal of either counting as a 'tackle'. Tag Rugby also varies in the fact that kicking the ball is not allowed.{{cite web|url=http://www.rfu.com/TheGame/FormsOfRugby/Tag.aspx |title=Tag Rugby |work=[[Rugby Football Union|RFU]] |date=11 April 2009 |accessdate=23 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110810133935/http://www.rfu.com/TheGame/FormsOfRugby/Tag.aspx |archivedate=10 August 2011 }} [[Mini rugby]] is another variant of rugby union aimed at fostering the sport in children.{{cite web|url=http://www.irishrugby.ie/downloads/REGULATIONS_Mini_Rugby_2012_to_2015(1).pdf |title=Mini and Leprechaun Rugby | work=irishrugby.ie |accessdate=27 February 2014}}{{cite book |last=Rutherford |first=Don |title=The Complete Book of Mini Rugby |publisher=Partridge |year=1993 |location=London |page=2 |url= |isbn=1-85225-196-4 }} It is played with only eight players and on a smaller pitch. Similar to Tag Rugby, [[American Flag Rugby]], (AFR), is a mixed gender, non-contact imitation of rugby union designed for American children entering grades K-9.{{cite news|url=http://www.americanflagrugby.com/about-afr.php |title=About AFR |work=americanflagrugby.com |accessdate=18 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110817210310/http://www.americanflagrugby.com/about-afr.php |archivedate=17 August 2011 }} Both American Flag Rugby and Mini Rugby differ to Tag Rugby in that they introduce more advanced elements of rugby union as the participants age. Other less formal variants include [[beach rugby]] and [[snow rugby]].{{cite web|url=http://www.irb.com/newsmedia/news/newsid=2026163.html |work=[[International Rugby Board|IRB]] |title=Rugby X-treme hits the Andes |first=Frankie |last=Deges |date=15 July 2008 |accessdate=24 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100726135403/http://www.irb.com/newsmedia/news/newsid=2026163.html |archivedate=26 July 2010 }} ==Influence on other sports== {{See also|History of American football|Comparison of American football and rugby union|Origins of Australian rules football|Comparison of rugby league and rugby union|History of rugby league}} [[File:Tom Wills 1857.jpg|thumb|When codifying [[Australian rules football]] in 1859, [[Tom Wills]] drew inspiration from an early version of rugby he learnt at Rugby School.]] [[Rugby league]] was formed as an administrative break from the English union before changing its laws, becoming a code in its own right. The two sports continue to influence each other to this day. [[American football]]{{Harvnb|Bath|1997|p=77}}{{Harvnb|Stubbs|2009|p=115}} and [[Canadian football]]{{Cite book |title=Encyclopedia Canadiana|volume = 8|editor=John Everett Robbins| year=1972 |publisher=Grolier of Canada|location=Toronto, Ottawa, Montreal |page=110 |isbn=0-7172-1601-2}} are derived from early forms of rugby. [[Australian rules football]] was influenced by [[rugby football]] and [[English public school football games|other games originating in English public schools]].{{cite book |last=Collins |first=Tony |editor-first=Stephen |editor-last=Wagg |title=Myths and Milestones in the History of Sport |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |year=2011 |pages=8–31 |chapter=Chapter 1: National Myths, Imperial Pasts and the Origins of Australian Rules Football |isbn=0-230-24125-5}}{{Cite book|last=Blainey|first=Geoffrey|title=A Game of Our Own: The Origins of Australian Football|publisher=Black Inc.|year=2010|pages=244–278|isbn=1-86395-347-7}}{{Cite book|last=de Moore|first=Greg|title=Tom Wills: His Spectacular Rise and Tragic Fall|publisher=Allen & Unwin|year=2008|pages=17–47|isbn=978-1-74175-499-5}} [[James Naismith]] took aspects of many sports including rugby to invent [[basketball]].{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1027613/index.htm |last=Wolff |first=Alexander |title=The Olden Rules |work=Sports Illustrated |date=25 November 2002 |accessdate=18 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604031625/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1027613/index.htm |archivedate=4 June 2011 }} The most obvious contribution is the [[jump ball]]'s similarity to the line-out as well as the underhand shooting style that dominated the early years of the sport. Naismith played rugby at [[McGill University]].{{cite web|url=http://www.naismithmuseum.com/main.php?action=cms.JamesNaismith |title=Biography of James Naismith |work=naismithmuseum.com |accessdate=27 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130914215653/http://www.naismithmuseum.com/main.php?action=cms.JamesNaismith |archivedate=14 September 2013 }} [[Swedish football (code)|Swedish football]] was a code whose rules were a mix of [[Laws of the Game (association football)|Association]] and [[Rugby football|Rugby football rules]].{{cite book |last=Jönsson |first=Åke |title=Fotboll: hur världens största sport växte fram |year=2006 |publisher=Historiska media |location=Lund |isbn=91-85377-48-1 |page=203}}{{cite web |url=https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=sv&u=https://svenskfotboll.se/svensk-fotboll/historia/svff-1904/&ei=p8V9TtHEKKSP0AXUvPUB&sa=X&oi=translate&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CB0Q7gEwAA&prev=/search%3Fq%3Dsvff:s%2Btillkomst%2B1904%26hl%3Den%26rls%3Dcom.microsoft:en-gb%26prmd%3Dimvns |title=SvFF:s tillkomst 1904 |work=svenskfotboll.se |accessdate=24 September 2011}} Rugby lends its name to [[wheelchair rugby]], a full-contact sport which contains elements of rugby such as crossing a try line with the ball to score.{{cite web |url=http://www.iwrf.com/?page=about_our_sport |title=Introduction to Wheelchair Rugby |work=iwrf.com |accessdate=28 September 2015}} ==Statistics and records== {{see also|List of top rugby union players by international caps|List of top scoring international rugby union players}} According to a 2011 report by the Centre for the International Business of Sport, over four and a half million people play rugby union or one of its variants organised by the IRB.{{cite web |url=http://www.stripes.com/military-life/they-re-game-rugby-team-willing-to-play-all-takers-1.146065 |title=They're game: Rugby team willing to play all takers |first=Seth |last=Robson |publisher=stripes.com |date=8 July 2011 |accessdate=25 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110814172158/http://www.stripes.com/military-life/they-re-game-rugby-team-willing-to-play-all-takers-1.146065 |archivedate=14 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }} This is an increase of 19 percent since the previous report in 2007.{{cite web |url=http://www.irb.com/mm/Document/NewsMedia/MediaZone/02/04/22/88/2042288_PDF.pdf |title=Economic Impact Report on Global Rugby; Part III: Strategic and Emerging Markets |publisher=Centre for the International Business of Sport, [[Coventry University]] |first=Simon |last=Chadwick |date=5 April 2011 |accessdate=25 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110626220118/http://www.irb.com/mm/Document/NewsMedia/MediaZone/02/04/22/88/2042288_PDF.pdf |archivedate=26 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }} The report also claimed that since 2007 participation has grown by 33 percent in Africa, 22 percent in South America and 18 percent in Asia and North America. In 2014 the IRB published a breakdown of the total number of players worldwide by national unions. It recorded a total of 6.6 million players globally, of those, 2.36 million were registered members playing for a club affiliated to their country's union. The 2016 World Rugby Year in Review reported 8.5 million players, of which 3.2 million were registered union players and 1.9 million were registered club players; 22% of all players were female.[http://publications.worldrugby.org/yearinreview2016/en/45-1 2016 Year in Review] - World Rugby The most capped international player from the tier 1 nations is former New Zealand openside flanker and captain [[Richie McCaw]] who has played in 148 internationals.{{cite web |url=http://stats.espnscrum.com/statsguru/rugby/stats/index.html?class=1;filter=advanced;orderby=matches;template=results;type=player |title=Statsguru/Test matches/Player records |publisher=ESPN Scrum.com |accessdate=27 February 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402010853/http://stats.espnscrum.com/statsguru/rugby/stats/index.html?class=1%3Bfilter%3Dadvanced%3Borderby%3Dmatches%3Btemplate%3Dresults%3Btype%3Dplayer |archive-date=2 April 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} While the top scoring tier 1 international player is New Zealand's [[Dan Carter]], who has amassed 1442 points during his career.{{cite web |url=http://stats.espnscrum.com/statsguru/rugby/stats/index.html?class=1;filter=advanced;orderby=points;template=results;type=player |title=Statsguru/Test matches/Player records |publisher=ESPN Scrum.com |accessdate=27 February 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811234407/http://stats.espnscrum.com/statsguru/rugby/stats/index.html?class=1%3Bfilter%3Dadvanced%3Borderby%3Dpoints%3Btemplate%3Dresults%3Btype%3Dplayer |archive-date=11 August 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} In April 2010 [[Rugby union in Lithuania|Lithuania]] which is a second tier rugby nation, broke the record of consecutive international wins for second tier rugby nations. In 2016, the All Blacks of New Zealand set the new record 18 consecutive test wins among tier 1 rugby nations, bettering their previous consecutive run of 17.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/oct/22/new-zealand-make-history-beat-australia-all-blacks-18-consecutive-wins |title=New Zealand sink Australia to make history with 18th consecutive Test win |publisher=The Guardian |date=22 October 2016 |accessdate=30 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100424222719/http://www.irb.com/newsmedia/news/newsid=2036957.html |archivedate=24 April 2010 }} This record was equalled by England on 11 March 2017 with a win over Scotland at Twickenham.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/rugby-union/39223528|title=Six Nations 2017: England 61-21 Scotland|date=2017-03-11|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2017-03-12|language=en-GB}} The highest scoring international match between two recognised unions was Hong Kong's 164–13 victory over Singapore on 27 October 1994.{{cite web|url=http://www.rugbydata.com/centuries |title=Games where 100 or more points were scored by a team |publisher=rugbydata.com |accessdate=27 September 2011}} While the largest winning margin of 152 points is held by two countries, Japan (a 155–3 win over Chinese Taipei) and Argentina (152–0 over Paraguay) both in 2002. The record attendance for a rugby union game was set on 15 July 2000 in which [[New Zealand national rugby union team|New Zealand]] defeated [[Australia national rugby union team|Australia]] 39–35 in a Bledisloe Cup game at [[Stadium Australia]] in [[Sydney]] before 109,874 fans.{{cite web|title=Records: Highest attendance|url=http://stats.espnscrum.com/scrum/rugby/records/team/highest_attendance.html?id=1;type=class|accessdate=14 May 2016|work=ESPN}} The record attendance for a match in Europe of 104,000 (at the time a world record) was set on 1 March 1975 when [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] defeated [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]] 12–10 at [[Murrayfield Stadium|Murrayfield]] in [[Edinburgh]] during the [[1975 Five Nations Championship]]. The record attendance for a domestic club match is 99,124, set when [[Racing 92]] defeated [[RC Toulonnais|Toulon]] in the [[2015–16 Top 14 season#Final|2016 Top 14 final]] on 24 June at [[Camp Nou]] in [[Barcelona]]. The match had been moved from its normal site of [[Stade de France]] near Paris due to scheduling conflicts with France's hosting of [[UEFA Euro 2016]].{{cite news|url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Rugby/Actualites/En-battant-toulon-le-racing-92-est-sacre-champion-de-france/698977 |title=En battant Toulon, le Racing 92 est sacré champion de France|trans-title=By beating Toulon, Racing 92 is champion of France|first=Romain |last=Bergogne |newspaper=[[L'Équipe]] |language=French |date=24 June 2016 |accessdate=25 June 2016}} ==In culture== [[File:Henri Rousseau - The Football Players.jpg|thumb|Henri Rousseau – ''The Football Players'' (1908)|alt=An oil painting of two groups of a pair of moustached men wearing stripped jerseys and shorts, contesting a rugby ball within an avenue of trees.]] Thomas Hughes 1857 novel ''[[Tom Brown's Schooldays]]'', set at [[Rugby School]], includes a rugby football match, also portrayed in the 1940s film of the same name. James Joyce mentions Irish team [[Bective Rangers]] in several of his works, including Ulysses (1922) and Finnegans Wake (1939), while his 1916 semi-autobiographical work ''[[A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man]]'' has an account of Ireland international [[James Magee]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bectiverangers.com/content/view/197/5 |title=Bective Rangers – James Joyce |work=bectiverangers.com |location=UK |accessdate=28 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726215801/http://www.bectiverangers.com/content/view/197/5/ |archivedate=26 July 2011 }} Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, in his 1924 Sherlock Holmes tale ''[[The Adventure of the Sussex Vampire]]'', mentions that Dr Watson played rugby for Blackheath.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/cult/vampires/classicstory/sussexvampire_p1.shtml|title=The Adventure of the Sussex Vampire |date=September 2005|work=BBC |location=UK |accessdate=28 August 2011 }} [[Henri Rousseau]]'s 1908 work ''Joueurs de football'' shows two pairs of rugby players competing.{{cite web |url=http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/collections/collection-online/show-full/piece/?search=The%20Football%20Players&page=&f=Title&object=60.1583 |title=Henri Rousseau |first=Cornelia |last=Lauf |work=guggenheim.org |accessdate=28 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429080822/http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/collections/collection-online/show-full/piece/?search=The%20Football%20Players&page=&f=Title&object=60.1583 |archivedate=29 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Other French artists to have represented the sport in their works include [[Albert Gleizes]]' ''Les Joueurs de football'' (1912), [[Robert Delaunay]]'s ''Football. L'Équipe de Cardiff'' (1916) and [[André Lhote]]'s ''Partie de Rugby'' (1917).{{cite book |last=Dine |first=Philip |title=French Rugby Football |year=2001 |page=19|publisher=Berg |location=Oxford |isbn=1-85973-327-1}} The [[Art competitions at the 1928 Summer Olympics|1928 Gold Medal for Art]] at the Antwerp Olympics was won by Luxembourg's [[Jean Jacoby]] for his work ''Rugby''.{{cite web |url=http://olympic-museum.de/art/1928.htm |title=Art Competitions |work=olympic-museum.de |accessdate=6 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080501132439/http://www.olympic-museum.de/art/1928.htm |archivedate=1 May 2008 |df=dmy-all }} In film, Ealing Studios' 1949 comedy ''[[A Run for Your Money]]'' and the 1979 BBC Wales television film ''[[Grand Slam (1978 film)|Grand Slam]]'' both centre on fans attending a match.{{cite book |last=Berry|first=David|title=Wales and Cinema, The First Hundred Years |year=1996 |publisher=University of Wales Press |location=Cardiff |page=215 |isbn=0-7083-1370-1}} Films that explore the sport in more detail include independent production ''[[Old Scores]]'' (1991) and ''[[Forever Strong]]'' (2008). ''[[Invictus (film)|Invictus]]'' (2009), based on [[John Carlin (journalist)|John Carlin]]'s book ''Playing the Enemy'', explores the events of the [[1995 Rugby World Cup]] and Nelson Mandela's attempt to use the sport to connect South Africa's people post-[[apartheid]].{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/portal/main.jhtml?view=DETAILS&grid=&xml=/portal/2007/10/19/ftmandela119.xml|title=How Nelson Mandela won the rugby World Cup |accessdate=28 August 2011|work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK |date=19 October 2007 | first=John | last=Carlin}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8406647.stm|title=South Africa 'rugby unity': Fact and fiction |date=11 December 2009|work=BBC News |location=UK |accessdate=28 August 2011 | first=Pumza | last=Fihlani}} In public art and sculpture there are many works dedicated to the sport. There is a 27 ft bronze statue of a rugby line-out by pop artist [[Gerald Laing]] at [[Twickenham Stadium|Twickenham]]{{cite web|url=http://www.yourlocalguardian.co.uk/news/local/richmondnews/8196778.Iconic_sculpture_of_rugby_line_out_unveiled/ |title=RFU unveils iconic bronze of rugby line-out by sculptor Gerald Laing |date=2 June 2010 |work=yourlocalguardian.co.uk |location=UK |accessdate=28 August 2011 | first=Joanna | last=Kilvington}} and one of rugby administrator Sir [[Tasker Watkins]] at the [[Millennium Stadium]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east/8360513.stm |title=Statue of Sir Tasker is unveiled |date=15 November 2009 |work=BBC News |location=UK |accessdate=23 September 2011 }} Rugby players to have been honoured with statues include [[Gareth Edwards]] in Cardiff and [[Danie Craven]] in Stellenbosch.{{cite web|url=http://www.rugby365.com/schools/craven/2504760.htm |title=Craven of Craven Week |date=27 June 2010 |work=rugby365.com |accessdate=28 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719053209/http://www.rugby365.com/schools/craven/2504760.htm |archivedate=19 July 2011 }} ==See also== {{Portal|Rugby union}} {{Wikinews category|Rugby}} * Houston, Texas | coordinates = {{coord|29.7267|-95.3452}} | broke_ground = 1994 | built = | opened = February 22, 1995 | renovated = 2013 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = {{nowrap|[[University of Houston System]]}} | operator = [[University of Houston]] | surface = Natural grass (1995–2014)
[[FieldTurf]] (2014–Present) | construction_cost = $30 million USDHolderfield, Jeff. [http://www.thedailycougar.com/static/vol60/95-02-22.html "New Cougar Field Opens Today at 4 P.M."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080907230043/http://www.thedailycougar.com/static/vol60/95-02-22.html |date=2008-09-07 }}. ''The Daily Cougar''. [[Conference USA Baseball Tournament|C-USA Tournament]] (2004, 2010) | seating_capacity = 5,000 | dimensions = Left Field: 330 ft (100 m)[http://www.ncaasports.com/baseball/mens/story/arc_story/18376 1999 Division I Baseball Regional Pairings and Site Breakdowns]. NCAA. Retrieved 13 November 2007.
Center Field: 400 ft (122 m)
Right Field: 330 ft (100 m) }} '''Darryl & Lori Schroeder Park''' (formerly known as '''Cougar Field''') is a [[baseball park]] in [[Houston, Texas]]. It is the home field of the [[Houston Cougars baseball]] team. Several iterations of the ballpark have existed. The current stadium holds 5,000 people, and opened for baseball in 1995. With a 1,500 square foot Daktronics video board, Schroeder Park features the second-largest scoreboard in college baseball. Since its opening, Schroeder Park has hosted several notable [[college baseball]] events.[http://uhcougars.cstv.com/trads/hou-trads-cougar.html Cougar Field]. UH Athletics. Retrieved 15 November 2007. In February 2016, the University of Houston announced that, as a response to a large donation to the baseball program, Cougar Field would be renamed Darryl & Lori Schroeder Park. [http://www.uhcougars.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/021116aab.html Cougar Field renamed]. UH Athletics. Retrieved 11 February 2016. ==History== Prior to 1961, the Cougars played at [[Buff Stadium]]. The original baseball stadium named Cougar Field was built roughly in the same area as the current one. Before 1968, it existed where [[Hofheinz Pavilion]] is today. To make room for the then new basketball arena, Cougar Field was moved next door.Scholl, Daniel. [http://www.thedailycougar.com/static/vol59/94-03-30.html "Dreams, Days Gone by Mark of Era"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090108141816/http://www.thedailycougar.com/static/vol59/94-03-30.html |date=2009-01-08 }}. ''The Daily Cougar''. Retrieved 13 November 2007. This iteration of Cougar Field stayed in the same location until March 29, 1994 when it was demolished in preparation for the establishment of the UH Athletics/Alumni center. To finish the rest of their season's home games, the Cougars played at [[Texas A&M University|Texas A&M University's]] [[Olsen Field]] and crosstown [[Rice University|Rice University's]] [[Reckling Park|Cameron Field]].Wizig, Jerry. [http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=1994_1191644 "Cougar Field Stories Abound"]. Chron.com. Houston Chronicle. Retrieved 13 November 2007.Carssow, Ryan. [http://www.thedailycougar.com/static/vol59/94-03-29.html "Only Memories Will Remain of Cougar Field"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080830025305/http://www.thedailycougar.com/static/vol59/94-03-29.html |date=2008-08-30 }}. ''The Daily Cougar''. Retrieved 13 November 2007. After a multimillion dollar donation from Cougar alumnus and [[San Diego Padres]] owner [[John Moores (baseball)|John Moores]], the current stadium was built throughout the remainder of the year, and had its first game on February 22, 1995. In late 2013, Houston, citing national competitiveness in recruiting, changed Schroeder Park's playing surface from natural grass to artificial turf.{{cite web |url=http://www.uhcougars.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/110113aab.html |title=Houston Baseball to Turf Cougar Field |publisher=Houston Cougars athletics |date=November 1, 2013 |accessdate=December 27, 2013}} In September 2015, Houston announced a new 20,000 square foot clubhouse and player development center to be constructed for Schroeder Park.{{cite web |url=http://blog.chron.com/sportsupdate/2015/09/uh-releases-rendering-for-new-baseball-facility-at-cougar-field |title=UH releases rendering for new baseball facility at Cougar Field |author=Duarte, Joseph |date=September 30, 2015 |publisher=[[Houston Chronicle]] |accessdate=December 3, 2015}} In October 2015, a new Daktronics video board with 1,500 square feet of space replaced the original one, and Schroeder Park became host to the largest scoreboard in college baseball. ==Events hosted== Since its opening in 1995, Schroeder Park has hosted several notable college baseball events. In, 1999, 2000,2015, and 2017 an [[NCAA Division I Baseball Championship|NCAA Regional]] was hosted at the ball park. Also in 2000, Schroeder Park was home to an [[NCAA Division I Baseball Championship|NCAA Super Regional]]. In addition, the [[2004 Conference USA Baseball Tournament|2004]] and [[2010 Conference USA Baseball Tournament|2010]] [[Conference USA Baseball Tournament]]s were both hosted at the ballpark. In 2014, the [[United States national baseball team|USA Baseball 18U National Team]] held trials at the ballpark.{{cite press release |url=http://web.usabaseball.com/article.jsp?ymd=20140824&content_id=91322452&vkey=news_usab |title=18U: Blue one-hits Red in 12-4 victory |publisher=USA Baseball |date=August 24, 2014 |accessdate=September 22, 2014}} ==Features== [[Image:Cougar Field scoreboard.jpg|thumb|Schroeder Park's former Philips Vidiwall scoreboard]] [[File:Cougar Field stands during game.JPG|thumb|Schroeder Park stands and press box during a game]] Schroeder Park is a scaled-down version of a major league ballpark. Until October 2015, it featured a scoreboard with a [[Philips]] Vidiwall LED video screen constructed by Spectrum Corporation.[http://www.spectrumscoreboards.com/products/scoreboards/default.html Scoreboards]. Spectrum Corporation. Retrieved 24 November 2007. It was replaced by a Daktronics video board, known as the "Sanders-Gutierrez Scoreboard", which is the second-largest in college baseball (behind only Arkansas' [[Baum Stadium]]).{{cite web |url=http://blog.chron.com/sportsupdate/2015/04/new-scoreboard-to-be-installed-at-cougar-field/ |title=Largest scoreboard in college baseball to be installed at Cougar Field |author=Duarte, Joseph |publisher=[[Houston Chronicle]] |date=April 16, 2015 |accessdate=December 3, 2015}} Schroeder Park seats up to 5,000 spectators, with most of the seats covered by a canopy roof. For players, in addition to locker rooms, there are facilities for indoor batting practice, storage, and laundry. Schroeder Park's press box seats 28, and has booths for television and radio coverage. The field is made of artificial turf, which can increase the running speed, but can also increase injuries as compared to natural grass. =={{Cite web|title = University of Houston Athletics :: UH Cougars :: Official Athletic Site|url = http://www.uhcougars.com/facilities/cougar-field-dev.html|website = www.uhcougars.com|accessdate = 2015-04-19}}Attendance== {| class="wikitable" revision.comment: /* Deciding if a goal has been scored */ passive voice → active voice
revision.text:
[[File:Nogomet Maribor - Varteks 1961 (4).jpg|thumb|A goal being scored]] In games of [[association football]] teams compete to score the most '''goals''' during the match. A goal is scored when the ball passes completely over a goal line at each end of the field of play between two centrally positioned upright goal posts 24 feet (7.32 m) apart and underneath a horizontal crossbar at a height of 8 feet (2.44 m) — this frame is also referred to as a [[Football_pitch#Goals|goal]]. Each team aims to score at one end of the pitch, while also preventing their opponents scoring at the other. Nets are usually attached to the goal frame to catch goalscoring balls.
==Rules== [[File:Ball in and out of play 2.svg|thumb|If the line in this diagram is the goal line between the goal posts, the only case in which a goal has been scored is position D.]] Rules concerning goal scoring are described in Law 10 of the [[Laws of the Game (association football)|Laws of the Game]]:
{{quote|text=A goal is scored when the whole of the ball passes over the goal line, between the goalposts and under the crossbar, provided that no [[Fouls and misconduct (association football)|infringement of the Laws of the Game]] has been committed previously by the team scoring the goal.|title=Law 10: The Method of Scoring<ref name="LOTG">{{cite web|title=LAWS OF THE GAME 2015/2016|url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/Document/FootballDevelopment/Refereeing/02/36/01/11/LawsofthegamewebEN_Neutral.pdf|website=FIFA.com|publisher=FIFA|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref>}}
As with other cases of the ball travelling [[Ball in and out of play|out of the field of play]], all of the ball must cross all of the line, otherwise play continues.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bray|first1=Ken|title=When is a goal not a goal?|url=https://plus.maths.org/content/when-goal-not-goal|website=plus.maths.org|accessdate=16 February 2018|language=en}}</ref> A goal is credited to the team attacking the goal scored upon, regardless of which team actually caused the ball to enter the goal. A ball entering a goal from the action of a player defending that goal is called an [[own goal]].
Even if serious foul play unambiguously prevents scoring a goal (a [[professional foul]]), a [[referee (association football)|referee]] cannot award a goal if it does not enter the goal as described above; i.e., there is no provision for awarding a goal akin to the [[penalty try]] in [[rugby football]] or the [[goaltending]] offence in [[basketball]].
A goal cannot be scored directly from an [[indirect free kick]] or a [[throw-in]]. Should the ball go into the goal from these without first being touched by another player, play is restarted with a [[goal kick]]. A player cannot score an own goal directly from ''any'' restart of play, in that case a [[corner kick]] would be awarded. Both of these situations, especially the latter, are exceedingly rare.
If there is time remaining in the session of play, after a goal has been scored play is restarted with a [[kick-off (association football)|kick-off]] by the side which conceded the goal.
===Deciding if a goal has been scored=== {{seealso|Goal-line technology|Video assistant referee}} Most goals are relatively unambiguous, as the ball will usually strike the net attached to the goal structure indicating that it passed the goal line as described above. Occasionally, however, situations occur where it is difficult for officials to tell if the ball completely crossed the goal line before a rebound, save, or clearance from the goal area. Additionally, even if the ball crosses the goal line as required, a goal may be disallowed if the attacking team commits an infringement of the Laws of the Game, such as the [[Offside (association football)|offside offence]] or a [[Fouls and misconduct (association football)|foul]].
As with all other decisions on the Laws of the Game, the referee is the final authority as to whether a goal is scored or disallowed. The match referee is advised by [[assistant referee (association football)|assistant referee]]s, whose view across the pitch from the sidelines may in some cases be more useful in determining whether the ball crossed the goal line or whether the attacking team committed an infringement.
The goal net was one of the earliest tools employed to aid match officials in determining whether a goal was scored. Introduced in the 1890s, the goal net provides a simple way to determine whether the ball passed on the correct side of the goal posts and crossbar. Although not mandated by the Laws of the Game, goal nets are now ubiquitous across most levels of organised football. Since 2012, [[goal-line technology]] has been used at the highest levels of professional football; it employs a system of cameras and sensors to provide the referee with a discreet signal when the ball has crossed the goal line.<ref name=IFABofficial>{{cite web|title=IFAB makes three unanimous historic decisions|url=https://www.fifa.com/about-fifa/news/y=2012/m=7/news=ifab-makes-three-unanimous-historic-decisions-1660541.html|website=FIFA.com|publisher=FIFA|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref> The [[video assistant referee]] was added in 2018 after years of trials; this is an additional assistant referee who constantly monitors video footage of the match and is empowered to advise the referee if he/she may have made a clear error in awarding a goal.
==Attribution of goals== The Laws make no mention of attributing goals to individual players. Nevertheless, goals are almost always attributed to individual players, that player being the one who provided the final action causing the goal to be scored. Generally, this is the last player to touch the ball, notwithstanding inconsequential deflections such as failed attempts at a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|save]]. Should a player cause a goal to be scored against their own team, the goal is recorded as an [[own goal]].
The authority on attributing goals varies between competitions. The [[Premier League]] in [[England]] has a dedicated [[Dubious Goals Committee]] for resolving attribution disputes.<ref name="DGC">{{ cite web| first1 = Sean | last1 = Ingle | first2 = Barry | last2 = Glendenning | first3 = James | last3 = Dart | url = http://football.guardian.co.uk/theknowledge/story/0,,1855736,00.html | title = Is there really a Dubious Goals Committee? | work = The Knowledge | publisher = The Guardian | date = 23 August 2006 | accessdate = 2010-05-28 }}</ref>
For an individual player, scoring multiple goals in a game is considered a notable achievement. In association football, a [[hat-trick]] refers to the uncommon feat of scoring three goals in a single game. Awards exist for individual players who score the most goals in some competitions, such awards are often called the "[[Golden Boot (disambiguation)|Golden Boot]]"<!--intentional link to DAB page-->.
==Goal celebrations== {{mainarticle|Goal celebration}} [[File:Atlético de Madrid - 01.jpg|thumb|right|[[Atlético Madrid]] players celebrate a goal with a group hug]] Players will typically celebrate scoring a goal with team mates, occasionally putting on elaborate displays for the crowd. The Laws allow this, but mandate that celebration must not be "excessive".<ref name="LOTG"/>
==Quantity of goals== On average, only a few scores occur per game in association football. {| class="wikitable" |+ Scoring rate in major competitions |- ! Competition !! Average number of goals per game |- | [[2015–16 Premier League]] || 2.70<ref name="wf_2015EPL">{{cite web|title=Premier League » Statistics » Goals per season|url=http://www.worldfootball.net/stats/eng-premier-league/1/|website=worldfootball.net|accessdate=15 December 2016}}</ref> |- | [[2015–16 Bundesliga]] || 2.83<ref name="wf_2015BUN">{{cite web|title=Bundesliga » Statistics » Goals per season|url=http://www.worldfootball.net/stats/Bundesliga/1/|website=worldfootball.net|accessdate=15 December 2016}}</ref> |- | [[2015–16 La Liga]] || 2.74<ref name="wf_2015LALIGA">{{cite web|title=Spain » Primera División » Statistics » Goals per season|url=http://www.worldfootball.net/stats/esp-primera-division/1/|website=worldfootball.net|accessdate=15 December 2016}}</ref> |- | [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] || 2.67<ref name="wf_2014WC">{{cite web|title=World Cup » Statistics » Goals per season|url=http://www.worldfootball.net/stats/wm/1/|website=worldfootball.net|accessdate=15 December 2016}}</ref> |- | [[2015 FIFA Women's World Cup]] || 2.81<ref name="wf_2015WWC">{{cite web|title=Women World Cup » Statistics » Goals per season|url=http://www.worldfootball.net/stats/frauen-wm/1/|website=worldfootball.net|accessdate=15 December 2016}}</ref> |} An analysis of several years' results from several English leagues found that 1–0 was the most common result, occurring in approximately 20% of games.<ref name="DSN_1">{{cite web|title=Most soccer matches are within one goal of 1-0|url=http://www.decisionsciencenews.com/2016/03/01/most-soccer-matches-are-within-one-goal-of-1-0/|website=Decision Science News|accessdate=15 December 2016}}</ref>

The team was founded in 1954 and play in the [[Burkinabé Second Division]].https://int.soccerway.com/teams/burkina-faso/sourou-sport-de-tougan/17224/ ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the 2000 capacity [[Stade Sangoulé-Lamizana]]. ==League participations== *'''[[Burkinabé Premier League]]: 2009–2013 *'''[[Burkinabé Second Division]]: 2013– ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://int.soccerway.com/teams/burkina-faso/sourou-sport-de-tougan/17224/ Soccerway] * [http://lefaso.net/spip.php?article37685 LeFaso] {{Burkinabé Premier League}} [[Category:Football clubs in Burkina Faso]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1954]] {{BurkinaFaso-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = State Farm Stadium | logo_image = [[File:State Farm Stadium logo.png|250px]] | image = [[File:Cardinals stadium crop.jpg|300px|center]] | address = 1 Cardinals Drive | location = [[Glendale, Arizona]] | coordinates = {{coord|33|31|39|N|112|15|45|W|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=inline,title}} | mass_excavation_began = July 31, 2003 | broke_ground = April 12, 2003 | opened = August 1, 2006 | renovated = 2014, 2017 | owner = [[Arizona Sports and Tourism Authority]] | operator = [[SMG (property management)|SMG]]{{Cite web |url=http://smgworld.com/news/smg-selected-manage-operate-maintain-market-university-phoenix-stadium/ |title=SMG Selected to Manage, Operate, Maintain and Market the University of Phoenix Stadium |access-date=2017-06-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170605073137/http://smgworld.com/news/smg-selected-manage-operate-maintain-market-university-phoenix-stadium/ |archive-date=2017-06-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }} | surface = Tifway 419 Hybrid Bermuda Grass | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]455 million[http://www.universityofphoenixstadium.com/index.php?page=stadium_facts§ion=statistics University of Phoenix Stadium] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100210114451/http://www.universityofphoenixstadium.com/index.php?page=stadium_facts§ion=statistics |date=2010-02-10 }} Funding & Economic Impact
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|455000000|2006}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = [[Peter Eisenman|Eisenman Architects]]
[[Populous (company)|Populous]] (then HOK Sport) | structural engineer = TLCP Structural, Inc. (bowl){{cite news|url=http://www.structuremag.org/article.aspx?articleID=535|title=The University of Phoenix Stadium Sets New Standards|publisher=STRUCTURE magazine|date=February 1, 2008|accessdate=May 12, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120526153935/http://structuremag.org/article.aspx?articleID=535|archivedate=May 26, 2012|df=}}
[[Walter P Moore Engineers and Consultants|Walter P Moore]][http://www.emporis.com/application/?lng=3&nav=building&id=259905 Emporis.com - University of Phoenix Stadium] to a design by [[Buro Happold]] (roof){{cite book |last=Gannon|first=Todd|title=Eisenman Architects/University of Phoenix Stadium for the Arizona Cardinals|publisher=Princeton Architectural Press|year=2008|location=New York|pages=100}} | services engineer = M-E Engineers, Inc.[http://www.me-engineers.com/projects/?office=global&category=professional_stadiums M-E Engineers, Inc. - Projects] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120523093410/http://www.me-engineers.com/projects/?office=global&category=professional_stadiums |date=2012-05-23 }} | general_contractor = [[Hunt Construction Group]][http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2006/09/20060918/This-Weeks-News/The-Cardinals-Signature-Stadium.aspx This Week's News: The Cardinals Signature Stadium] | former_names = Cardinals Stadium (August–September 2006)
University of Phoenix Stadium (2006–2018) | tenants = [[Arizona Cardinals]] ([[National Football League|NFL]]) (2006–present)
[[Fiesta Bowl]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (2007–present) | parking = 14,000 on-site parking spaces | suites = 88 | seating_capacity = 63,400 (expandable to 72,200; standing room to at least 78,600{{cite news |url=http://www.buccaneers.com/news/newsdetail.aspx?newsid=6289|title=The Big Game On the Horizon|publisher=Buccaneers.com|date=February 9, 2008|accessdate=February 13, 2008}}[http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/boxscore?gameId=310102483 Auburn Claims SEC's Fifth Straight National Title By Dropping Oregon On Late Field Goal]) | field_dimensions = 134 yds x 78 yrds (122m x 71m) }} '''State Farm Stadium''', formerly known as '''University of Phoenix Stadium''', is a multi-purpose [[American football|football]] [[stadium]] located in [[Glendale, Arizona]], west of [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]]. It is the home of the [[Arizona Cardinals]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL) and the annual [[Fiesta Bowl]]. It replaced [[Tempe, Arizona|Tempe]]'s [[Sun Devil Stadium]] as the [[Phoenix metropolitan area|Valley of the Sun]]'s main stadium. The stadium is adjacent to the [[Gila River Arena]] and it features the first fully retractable natural grass playing surface built in the United States on top of an AirField Systems drainage system. An opening on one side of the stadium allows the playing field to move to the exterior of the building, allowing the entire natural turf playing surface to be exposed to daylight and also allowing the floor of the stadium to be used for any other purpose (such as seating for concerts or to accommodate motorsports events) without damaging the turf. The stadium has hosted the [[Fiesta Bowl]], the [[2007 BCS National Championship Game]], [[2011 BCS National Championship Game]] and [[2016 College Football Playoff National Championship]], which set the venue's entertainment attendance record of 78,603 on January 11, 2011,{{cite news |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/news/2011/01/10/bcs-game-sets-new-university-of.html|first=Mike|last=Sunnucks|title=BCS Game Sets New University of Phoenix Stadium Attendance Record|date=January 11, 2011|accessdate=January 11, 2011}} 2008 [[Super Bowl]] [[Super Bowl XLII|XLII]], 2015 [[Super Bowl XLIX]], 2023 [[Super Bowl LVII]], the [[2015 Pro Bowl]], [[WrestleMania XXVI]], and matches from the [[2015 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]. It was one of the stadiums for the [[Copa América Centenario]] in 2016, with one of those matches being the 3rd place final. It hosted the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|NCAA Final Four]] in 2017 and will do so again in 2024. The [[University of Phoenix]] acquired the [[naming rights]] in September 2006, shortly after the stadium had opened under the name '''Cardinals Stadium''' and retained the rights until September 2018. The "University of Phoenix" name was applied as a corporate sponsor, and not as the home stadium of the university, which has no intercollegiate athletics program (the university is a private, for-profit venture). On September 4, 2018, [[State Farm]] acquired the naming rights. The Cardinals and State Farm reached agreement on an 18-year commitment that resulted in the team’s home venue becoming State Farm Stadium.{{cite news|last=Urban|first=Darren|title=New Name For Cardinals’ Nest: State Farm Stadium|url=https://www.azcardinals.com/news/new-name-for-cardinals-nest-state-farm-stadium|publisher=NFL Enterprises, LLC|website=AZCardinals.com|date=September 4, 2018|accessdate=September 26, 2018}}{{cite press release|title=Cardinals Reach Naming Rights Agreement with State Farm; Iconic Arizona Venue to be Known as State Farm Stadium|url=https://newsroom.statefarm.com/state-farm-stadium-announcement-phoenix/|publisher=State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company|website=Newsroom.StateFarm.com|date=September 4, 2018|accessdate=September 26, 2018}} ==Facility information and history== Since moving to Arizona from [[St. Louis]], [[Missouri]] in 1988, the Cardinals had played at [[Sun Devil Stadium]] on the campus of [[Arizona State University]]. The Cardinals had only planned to play there until a new stadium could be built in Phoenix. However, the [[savings and loan crisis]] derailed funding for a new stadium during the 1990s. Over time, the Cardinals expressed frustration at being merely tenants in a college football stadium. The lack of having their own stadium denied them additional revenue streams available to other NFL teams. The Cardinals campaigned several years in the years prior to its construction for a new and more modern facility. The ceremonial groundbreaking for the new stadium was held on April 12, 2003, and the 63,400-seat stadium opened on August 1, 2006 after three years of construction. The stadium was designed by Eisenman Architects and HOK Sport (now [[Populous (company)|Populous]]).[http://www.universityofphoenixstadium.com/index.php/stadium/statistics Stadium Statistics] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120611025603/http://www.universityofphoenixstadium.com/index.php/stadium/statistics |date=2012-06-11 }} The stadium is considered an architectural icon for the region and was named by ''[[Business Week]]'' as one of the 10 “most impressive” sports facilities on the globe due to the combination of its retractable roof (engineering design by [[Walter P Moore Engineers and Consultants|Walter P Moore]]) and roll-in natural grass field,{{Cite web|url=http://www.lloydengineers.com/professional-international/|title=www.lloydengineers.com|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} similar to the [[GelreDome]] and the [[Veltins-Arena]].[http://images.businessweek.com/ss/06/02/sports_stadiums/source/9.htm World-Class Sports Stadiums: BusinessWeek] [[Light emitting diode|LED]] video and ribbon displays from [[Daktronics]] in [[Brookings, South Dakota]] were installed in 2006 prior to Arizona's first game of the season at the new stadium.{{cite web|url=http://svconline.com/avcontrol/features/avinstall_installation_spotlight_university_2/|title=Installation Spotlight: University of Phoenix Stadium, Glendale, Ariz.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100203070758/http://svconline.com/avcontrol/features/avinstall_installation_spotlight_university_2/|archivedate=2010-02-03|df=}} The cost of the project was [[United States dollar|$]]455 million. That total included $395.4 million for the stadium, $41.7 million for site improvements, and $17.8 million for the land. Contributors to the stadium included the [[Arizona Sports and Tourism Authority]] ($302.3 million), the [[Arizona Cardinals]] ($143.2 million), and the [[Glendale, Arizona|City of Glendale]] ($9.5 million). [[File:Cardinalsfield.jpg|175px|left|thumb|The playing field outside and lined for the Arizona Cardinals.]] [[File:University of Phoenix Stadium no field.jpg|175px|right|thumb|The interior of State Farm Stadium with field removed. To protect the stadium's grass playing surface, non-sporting events are always held with the facility in this configuration.]] The stadium has 88 [[luxury suites]] — called luxury lofts — with space for 16 future suites as the stadium matures. The {{convert|25|acre}} surrounding the stadium is called Sportsman's Park. Included within the Park is an {{convert|8|acre|sing=on}} landscaped tailgating area called the Great Lawn. There are no obstructed view seats in the stadium. There are visible areas in the upper deck of the end zone where seats could have been put in but were not due to the giant super columns supporting the roof structure. [[File:cardswin1.jpg|175px|left|thumb|Cardinals win NFC Championship, January 18, 2009]] The stadium [[seating capacity]] can be expanded by 8,800 for "mega-events" such as college bowls, NFL Super Bowls, and the NFC Championship Game{{cite news |title=Cards vs. Eagles Sells Out in 6 Minutes|first=Carrie|last=Watters|url=http://www.azcentral.com/sports/cardinals/articles/2009/01/11/20090111cardsellout-CR.html|newspaper=[[The Arizona Republic]]|date=January 11, 2009|accessdate=January 12, 2009}} by adding risers and ganged, portable "X-frame" folding seats. The endzone area on the side of the facility where the field tray rolls in and out of the facility can be expanded to accommodate the additional seats. The roof is made out of [[translucent]] [[Taiyo Kogyo Corporation#BirdAir|Birdair]] fabric and opens in 12 minutes. It is the first retractable roof ever built on an incline. ==Events== [[File:University of Phoenix Stadium roof.jpg|175px|left|thumb|The roof of State Farm Stadium.]] Events held at the stadium include [[Arizona Cardinals]] home games; public grand opening tours held August 19 and 20, 2006 (attended by 120,000 people); various shows, expositions, tradeshows and motor sport events; the AIA 4A and 5A state championship games for football; and international soccer exhibition matches. The multipurpose nature of the facility has allowed it to host 91 events representing 110 event days between the dates of August 4, 2006 through the [[2007 BCS National Championship Game|BCS National Championship]] January 8, 2007. ===NFL=== The first preseason football game was played August 12, 2006 when the Cardinals defeated the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]], 21–13. The first regular season game was played September 10 against the [[San Francisco 49ers]] (the Cardinals won 34–27). The stadium's air-conditioning system made it possible for the Cardinals to play at home on the opening weekend of the NFL season for the first time since moving to Arizona in 1988. On October 16, 2006, the stadium hosted a notable game between the Cardinals and the undefeated [[Chicago Bears]] where the [[2006 Chicago Bears–Arizona Cardinals game|Bears came back from a 20-point deficit to defeat the Cardinals]]. The Bears would later go on to play in [[Super Bowl XLI]]. University of Phoenix Stadium hosted [[Super Bowl XLII]] on February 3, 2008 in which the [[New York Giants]] defeated the [[2007 New England Patriots season|previously undefeated]] [[New England Patriots]] 17–14 with a paid attendance crowd of 71,101. This was the second time the [[Phoenix metropolitan area|Phoenix area]] hosted a [[Super Bowl]], the other being [[Super Bowl XXX]] held in nearby [[Tempe, Arizona|Tempe]] at [[Sun Devil Stadium]] in 1996 when the [[Dallas Cowboys]] defeated the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]]. The Cardinals' first home playoff game since 1947 took place at the stadium on January 3, 2009, with Arizona beating the [[Atlanta Falcons]], 30–24. The stadium also hosted the [[NFL playoffs, 2008–09#NFC: Philadelphia Eagles at Arizona Cardinals|2008-09 NFC Championship Game]] between the Cardinals and [[Philadelphia Eagles]] on January 18, 2009, which the Cardinals won 32–25 in front of over 70,000 fans in attendance. The [[2015 Pro Bowl]] was the first Pro Bowl to be held at the same location as the same year's Super Bowl since 2010. The Pro Bowl returned to Hawaii in 2016.{{cite web|title=2015 Pro Bowl to be played in Arizona - NFL.com|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap2000000340271/article/2015-pro-bowl-to-be-played-in-arizona|accessdate=April 9, 2014}} On February 1, 2015, the [[New England Patriots]] defeated the [[Seattle Seahawks]] in [[Super Bowl XLIX]] held at the stadium. [[File:UniversityofPhoenixStadiumnasa.png|175px|right|thumb|State Farm Stadium from a [[bird's-eye view]]]] ===College football=== The stadium was the venue for the [[2007 Fiesta Bowl|Fiesta Bowl]] on January 1, 2007 featuring the [[Boise State]] Broncos vs. the [[University of Oklahoma]] Sooners (Boise State won 43-42 in overtime); and the BCS National Championship on January 8, 2007 between the (1) [[Ohio State]] Buckeyes and the (2) [[University of Florida]] Gators, which the Gators won 41-14. It also hosted the [[2008 Fiesta Bowl]] between the [[Oklahoma Sooners]] and the [[West Virginia University Mountaineers]], as well as the [[2009 Fiesta Bowl]] between the [[Texas Longhorns]] and the [[Ohio State Buckeyes]]. It has also held many high school graduations. On January 10, 2011, the [[2011 BCS National Championship Game]] between the Auburn Tigers and the Oregon Ducks had an attendance record setting 78,603 on hand for the game. On January 11, 2016, University of Phoenix Stadium hosted the [[College Football Playoff]] National Championship Game featuring No. 2 ranked [[Alabama Crimson Tide]] and No. 1 ranked [[Clemson Tigers]]. ===College basketball=== [[File:Glendale-University of Phoenix Stadium.jpg|250px|thumb|left|2017 NCAA Final Four]] Before 2018 the venue was known as University of Phoenix Stadium. It hosted the [[NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Championship]] in 2017. State Farm Stadium will host the Final Four in 2024. ===Soccer=== {{refimprove|section|date=October 2018}} On February 7, 2007, the stadium hosted a soccer match attended by 62,462 fans. The [[United States men's national soccer team]] defeated [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]], 2–0. On January 21, 2012, the U.S. played against [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela]] and won the match 1–0. On January 30, 2013, [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] played against [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]], a game that was broadcast on [[Televisa Deportes]], [[UniMás]], and [[TV Azteca]]. The match ended in a 1–1 draw.http://www.azcentral.com/sports/azetc/ar On November 19, 2015, the stadium was one of the sites selected for the 2016 [[Copa América Centenario]].{{cite web|url=http://www.concacaf.com/article/ten-metropolitan-areas-from-across-the-united-states-selected-to-host-copa-america-centenario|title=Ten Metropolitan Areas from Across the United States Selected to Host Copa America Centenario|publisher=CONCACAF.com|date=19 November 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.conmebol.com/es/19112015-1300/diez-areas-metropolitanas-de-estados-unidos-han-sido-seleccionadas-para-la|title=Diez áreas metropolitanas de Estados Unidos han sido seleccionadas para la organización de la Copa América Centenario|publisher=CONMEBOL.com|date=19 November 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ussoccer.com/stories/2015/11/19/15/05/151119-mnt-ten-metropolitan-areas-across-the-us-selected-to-host-copa-america-centenario|title=Ten Metropolitan Areas from Across the United States Selected to Host Copa America Centenario|publisher=US Soccer|date=19 November 2015}} The stadium hosted three matches, including Mexico vs. [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] on June 5, and the third-place match (United States vs. [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]]) on June 25. In club soccer, [[Real Madrid]] battled MLS side [[LA Galaxy]] in August 2013. The Spanish side defeated the Galaxy 3–1. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:95%;" style="text-align:center" |- !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Arizona Cardinals|border=2}};"|Date !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Arizona Cardinals|border=2}};"|Winning Team !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Arizona Cardinals|border=2}};"|Result !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Arizona Cardinals|border=2}};"|Losing Team !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Arizona Cardinals|border=2}};"|Tournament !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Arizona Cardinals|border=2}};"|Spectators |- |style="text-align:center;|February 7, 2007||'''{{fb|USA}}'''||style="text-align:center;|2–0||{{fb|MEX}}||style="text-align:center;|International Friendly||style="text-align:center;|62,462 |- |style="text-align:center;|January 21, 2012||'''{{fb|USA}}'''||style="text-align:center;|1–0||{{fb|VEN}}||style="text-align:center;|Friendly||style="text-align:center;|22,403 |- |style="text-align:center;|January 30, 2013||{{fb|MEX}}||style="text-align:center;|1–1||{{fb|DEN}}||style="text-align:center;|Friendly||style="text-align:center;|43,345 |- |style="text-align:center;|June 5, 2016||'''{{fb|MEX}}'''||style="text-align:center;|3–1||{{fb|URU}}||style="text-align:center;|[[Copa América Centenario Group C]]||style="text-align:center;|60,025 |- |style="text-align:center;|June 8, 2016||{{fb|ECU}}||style="text-align:center;|2–2||{{fb|PER}}||style="text-align:center;|[[Copa América Centenario Group B]]||style="text-align:center;|11,937 |- |style="text-align:center;|June 25, 2016||'''{{fb|COL}}'''||style="text-align:center;|1–0||{{fb|USA}}||style="text-align:center;|[[Copa América Centenario]] Third place playoff||style="text-align:center;|29,041 |} ===WWE=== [[Image:WMXXVIlive.jpg|right|thumb|upright|An attendance record setting 72,219 fans at the State Farm Stadium for WrestleMania XXVI]] The stadium hosted the [[WWE]] event [[WrestleMania XXVI]] with 72,219 fans in attendance. The event was held in the stadium on March 28, 2010. WrestleMania XXVI was the twenty-sixth annual [[WrestleMania]] [[professional wrestling]] [[pay-per-view]] event produced by [[WWE|World Wrestling Entertainment]] (WWE), which took place on March 28, 2010, at the venue when it was known as University of Phoenix Stadium in the [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]] suburb of [[Glendale, Arizona]].{{cite web|url=http://corporate.wwe.com/news/2009/2009_02_24.jsp|title=Arizona Hosts WrestleMania XXVI|date=February 24, 2009|publisher=[[World Wrestling Entertainment]]|accessdate=February 24, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227150114/http://corporate.wwe.com/news/2009/2009_02_24.jsp|archivedate=February 27, 2009|df=}} This was the first WrestleMania since [[WrestleMania XI]] with a non-title match as a main event, the first WrestleMania to be held in the state of [[Arizona]] and the third to be held in an open-air venue,{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/magazine/magazinefeatures10/featureoftheweek20100212/|title=WWE Magazine Feature of the Week|publisher=[[World Wrestling Entertainment]]|date=February 13, 2010|accessdate=February 13, 2010}} after [[WrestleMania IX]] and [[WrestleMania XXIV]]. WrestleMania XXVI was a [[WWE Brand Extension|joint-promotion]] event, with performers both from the [[WWE Raw|Raw]] and [[WWE SmackDown|SmackDown]] brands. The event's [[Card (sports)|card]] consisted of eight matches, including three main matches. The first of these matches was a [[hardcore wrestling|no disqualification, no count-out]] match, in which [[The Undertaker]] defeated [[Shawn Michaels]] to improve his [[The Undertaker#WrestleMania record|undefeated WrestleMania streak]] to 18–0. Per the pre-match stipulation, Michaels was [[Professional wrestling match types#Retirement match|forced to retire]]. The second was a [[Professional wrestling match types#Singles match|singles match]] for the [[WWE World Heavyweight Championship|WWE Championship]] that saw [[John Cena]] defeat [[Dave Batista|Batista]] to win the championship. The third saw [[World Heavyweight Championship (WWE)|World Heavyweight Champion]], [[Chris Jericho]], defeat [[Edge (wrestler)|Edge]] to retain the title. The [[Card (sports)|undercard]] also included a [[Hardcore wrestling|No Holds Barred match]] between [[Bret Hart]] and [[Vince McMahon|Mr. McMahon]] and the sixth annual [[Money in the Bank ladder match]]. Tickets for the event commenced sale to the public on November 7, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.universityofphoenixstadium.com/?page=events§ion=view_event&event_id=105|title=WWE Presents WrestleMania XXVI|publisher=University of Phoenix Stadium|accessdate=August 29, 2009}} WrestleMania XXVI generated approximately 885,000 PPV buys, [[gross (economics)|grossing]] [[United States dollar|US$]]49 million in revenue.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1273158888|title=WWE PPV buyrate numbers in 2010|publisher=Wrestleview.com|accessdate=May 6, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Co55AXQc?url=http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1273158888|archivedate=December 10, 2012|df=}} With an attendance of 72,219, the event grossed $5.8 million in ticket sales, making the event the highest grossing and attended entertainment event held at the University of Phoenix Stadium.{{cite web|url=http://corporate.wwe.com/news/2010/2010_3_28.jsp|title=WrestleMania XXVI Breaks Record|publisher=[[World Wrestling Entertainment]]|date=March 28, 2010|accessdate=March 29, web|url=http://corporate.wwe.com/news/2007/2007_04_21.jsp|title=WrestleMania Blows Away Attendance Record At Ford Fields|publisher=[[World Wrestling Entertainment]]|date=April 21, 2007|accessdate=March 29, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070418144247/http://corporate.wwe.com/news/2007/2007_04_21.jsp|archivedate=April 18, 2007|df=}}{{cite It has also held many high school graduations. On August 1, 2009, the stadium hosted [[Monster Jam]] Summer Heat, with Maximum Destruction defeating Captain's Curse in the racing finals and Grave Digger winning the freestyle event. The stadium hosted the inaugural [[Stadium Super Trucks]] race on April 6, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://stadiumsupertrucks.com/ssts/tour/ |title=Schedule |work=[[Stadium Super Trucks]] |accessdate=October 18, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019124159/http://stadiumsupertrucks.com/ssts/tour/ |archivedate=October 19, 2013 |df= }} On January 30, 2016, [[Monster Jam]] returned to the stadium for the first time since 2009, with 16 of the best trucks. On February 6, the [[AMA Supercross Championship]] raced for the first time, after visiting [[Chase Field]] from 1999 to 2015. {{wide image|UnivOfPhxStad 09272009 pregamePano.jpg|1000px|A panoramic view of the interior of the stadium before a Cardinals football game, September 27, 2009}} ==Naming rights== [[File:University of Phoenix Stadium field 01.jpg|200 px|right|thumb|The movable field outside of the stadium.]] On September 26, 2006 the [[University of Phoenix]] acquired the naming rights to the stadium totalling $154.5 million over 20 years.{{cite news |url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/0926stadiumfolo26-ON.html|title=Stadium Name Deal: $154.5 mil Over 20 Years|first=Scott|last=Wong|newspaper=[[The Arizona Republic]]|date=September 26, 2006|accessdate=September 26, 2006}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} On April 11, 2017, the University of Phoenix terminated the naming rights just 11 years into the 20-year deal, citing financial woes; however, the university kept its name on the stadium until a replacement company was found to give naming rights to. On September 4th, 2018, [[State Farm]] reached a deal securing the rights through 2036. University of Phoenix will remain involved as a sponsor with the team in a reduced capacity as the Cardinals' "official education partner." == Parking space == The stadium has approximately 14,000 on-site parking spaces (plus 12,000 adjacent spaces),[http://www.universityofphoenixstadium.com/stadium/statistics Statistics - University of Phoenix Stadium] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622142913/http://universityofphoenixstadium.com/stadium/statistics |date=2013-06-22 }} located in numerous lots that surround the stadium's 2,000 disabled parking spaces. The design improvement, featured for example in a Discovery program about this stadium, is zoning. Parking spaces for guests are zoned with preferred leaving directions, to achieve the fastest possible movement of traffic.[http://www.universityofphoenixstadium.com/guest/directions Parking & Directions - University of Phoenix Stadium] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622152728/http://universityofphoenixstadium.com/guest/directions |date=2013-06-22 }} {{clear}} ==Notes and references== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.azcardinals.com/stadium/ Arizona Cardinals' website for stadium] *[http://www.universityofphoenixstadium.com/ Global Spectrum’s website for stadium] *[http://www.az-sta.com/ Arizona Sports and Tourism Authority] *[https://seatingchartview.com/university-phoenix-stadium/ University of Phoenix Stadium Seating Chart] {{Navboxes| |title=State Farm Stadium succession and navigation boxes |list1= {{S-start-collapsible|header={{S-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
